review: I love the way that Banville writes. Nothing feels colder or more bleak and hopeless than the setting of this detective novel, which takes place at ChI love the way that Banville writes. Nothing feels colder or more bleak and hopeless than the setting of this detective novel, which takes place at Christmas but feels more like the deadest of dead winters in a smallish village in the 1950s, where Protestants are despised and where they equally disdain the Catholics and their power. So the vibe is there and I'd read more novels with St. John Strafford as the lead. All of the women in this novel, however, are mentally ill, frigid, or sex-crazed (or just middle-aged with zero personality). The men are varied but traumatized, repressed. The story is good and I think I'll long remember reading this one, but some aspects of it left me dissatisfied. ...more

review: When I was listening to this, it seemed somewhat derivative of other ghost stories/historical fiction from the era and the characters were not particuWhen I was listening to this, it seemed somewhat derivative of other ghost stories/historical fiction from the era and the characters were not particularly well drawn. Famous real life historical personages and fictional ones, as well, gather on a British island to investigate the disappearance of a whole family in the early 1900s. Some of the group are sceptics and others are agnostic. So it's a good setup. But the execution didn't pay off. The female characters in particular were unnuanced and their dialogue was flat. There was a lot of atmospheric tension and a good representation of the development of new technology cloaked by the trend of spiritualism of the time. But the conclusion, and in particular the ending, absolutely did not work for me. ...more

review: Faith is a solid, thoughtful novel about a family in crisis caused in part by the Catholic Church abuse revelations in Boston around 2002. The narratoFaith is a solid, thoughtful novel about a family in crisis caused in part by the Catholic Church abuse revelations in Boston around 2002. The narrator is Sheila, a single woman in her thirties who has two brothers. She slowly reveals their story by looking back at her family through the years leading up to an allegation against her brother, a priest, Arthur, and how it affects them and their already terse communications. What sticks out to me are the particularities of the neighborhood and how the politics of the Church dominates everyday life for its parishioners until scrutiny causes people like Sheila to move far away from its prying eyes. This is a book I looked forward to returning to because of its strong characters and observations. ...more

review: Closer to 3.5 stars.While there were several standout contributions to this collection (listed below), there were a few that simply didn't rise to theCloser to 3.5 stars.While there were several standout contributions to this collection (listed below), there were a few that simply didn't rise to the level of a best story. In a couple of cases, the stories felt like they might still be in need of more polishing and development. Furthermore, it is one of my biggest pet peeves that chapters of novels are treated as short stories, even if the writing is excellent. The short story as its own artform should be celebrated and knowing that a "story" is a chapter of a novel removes the context that situates it into a greater work. Best stories from 2023:The Master Mourner, Benjamin ErlichThe Company of Others, Sara FreemanAnnunciation, Lauren GroffThe Mine, Nathan HarrisThe Muddle, Sana KrasikovPeking Duck, Ling MaSupernova, Kosiso UgwuezeIt Is What It Is, Azareen Van der Vliet Oloom (my favorite)...more

review: While I liked the style of this novella (a sort of rambling monologue of reminiscences from a lonely, disappointed divorcee), most of it is rather munWhile I liked the style of this novella (a sort of rambling monologue of reminiscences from a lonely, disappointed divorcee), most of it is rather mundane and self-absorbed. review: I read this years ago for the first time and had only a vague memory of the novel. So this time around, I found a funny satire about the world of liteI read this years ago for the first time and had only a vague memory of the novel. So this time around, I found a funny satire about the world of literary fame and scholarship. Four characters have a vested personal interest in the life and poetry of a tragic self-taught poet named Mary Swann, who was tragically murdered by her husband and left little trace of her life aside from the poems she wrote on scraps of paper. Each of the four gets their own section and we learn all about them. However, the form takes a jarring turn for the final quarter of the book from straight narrative into a more meta take via screenplay and for me, it doesn’t work and in fact derails the novel. So what was rather pleasurable becomes more tedious. The pleasure of Shields’ prose work in the earlier sections foretells her (better) novels to come. ...more

title: Bliss Montage
author: Ma, Ling*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The stories in this collection are all good, and a couple of them will stick with me for a long time. The first two are connected in an odd way and plThe stories in this collection are all good, and a couple of them will stick with me for a long time. The first two are connected in an odd way and play off of each other as a woman in a lonely marriage recounts a previous boyfriend who was physically abusive. In the first, there's a detachment and it plays with language and form, but in the second more conventional narrative, the same protagonist follows the same abusive boyfriend around town years later to enact a form of vengeance. The stories I'll remember for a long time are G, The Returning, and Peking Duck, which is an examination of stories and authorship as a writer uses one of her mother's actual life events to build a story of her own. When we get to the final scene, there's a lot to think about. I can't wait to see which story is featured in Best American Short Stories 2023, ed. Min Jin Lee. If you liked Ling Ma's first novel, Severance, you'll like these stories. If you like these stories, you might try the novel....more

review: This is a novel of childhood set in 1940s Ireland, where the unnamed protagonist recalls the past in an exuberant narrative from the second person perThis is a novel of childhood set in 1940s Ireland, where the unnamed protagonist recalls the past in an exuberant narrative from the second person perspective. You (she) tells her life in an stream of consciousness style that slowly reveals the details of family life, what it's like in school and dreaming and laughing with other people in the town. When the older sister Emma's comes home for a visit, there is a shift as the parents are confronted with Emma's adult life and choices, and this deeply affects their relationship with the narrator, as well. It's a relatively short novel with a cataclysmic escalation of disappointments. The novel contains themes that O'Brien has used in earlier novels and short stories, but there's a new level of maturity here in this 1970 work. ...more

review: What I loved about this novel:The vivid descriptions of physicality, whether it's movement in creation of art or working in a cafe, or sexual encounteWhat I loved about this novel:The vivid descriptions of physicality, whether it's movement in creation of art or working in a cafe, or sexual encounters, the bodies of characters and the way they move and intersect are at the forefront.The elevated writing style that gives an elegance to the characters that feels out of time. The narrative tone stays consistent from beginning to end. How the characters, just coming out of grad school, are on the precipice of the next phase of their lives and they are unsure of themselves or the choices they've made, which feels true to life. Most of the group of loose friends are gay and there is a fluidity to connections and disconnections.The novel examines nuances in race and class identities but doesn't sacrifice the specificity of each character. What I liked less:There were many characters and none of them are the protagonist of the novel, so there is no central focus. There is also no central plot other than the one that surrounds a looming end to grad school. It was sometimes hard to remember who was who. In that sense, it felt more like connected short stories. ...more

review: For bookclub.Like other Lisa See novels I've read, The Island of Sea Women does a good job of teaching Asian history to presumably white American readFor bookclub.Like other Lisa See novels I've read, The Island of Sea Women does a good job of teaching Asian history to presumably white American readers. The characters are distinctly drawn and the plot moves along through the years to tell a compelling story. However, See's books always seem to be shaped in a particular way to blur cultural distinctions so that in dialog and narrative, the characters feel "American." One minor instance of this would be the novel's reliance on the Swiss novel, Heidi, as a cultural touchstone. Surely there are plenty of Korean novels that could have been used as a book many Koreans knew about? In any case, I did learn about historical events and cared about the characters and look forward to seeing what other people in my reading group think....more

review: If you follow the news or cultural criticism at all, you already know that Hollywood has a systemic issue with bad behavior, group think, outrageous bIf you follow the news or cultural criticism at all, you already know that Hollywood has a systemic issue with bad behavior, group think, outrageous bullying, and a deification of (male) "creative genius" that justifies anything. Maureen Ryan's book takes a deep dive into particular studios and/or shows where these abuses were allowed to fester, hurting a lot of (mostly marginalized people.) And we all tend toward cognitive dissonance while we enjoy the shows and movies and try to ignore the ugliness that might have surrounded the experience of production. It's a groundbreaking compilation of some of the worst things that happen, well documented and expressive. ...more

title: Day
author: Cunningham, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Three days in 2019, 2020, and 2021 are the structure from which to examine the private thoughts of seven characters before and during the beginnings oThree days in 2019, 2020, and 2021 are the structure from which to examine the private thoughts of seven characters before and during the beginnings of the recent pandemic in this novel. There is one character who is essentially the center of the universe for his sister, her husband, and her children. Everyone loves Robbie and Robbie loves them all in return. But as far as affection goes between all the other characters? Isabel and her husband, Dan? No. Isabel and her children? No. Isabel is depressed and detached and that's before they are all quarantined. There is a lot to be revealed in faked social media posts, unsent letters, texts, and long stretches of chilly conversation. Perhaps that's one of the points of this story, that we are all disconnected from our real lives due in part to fear of the future, the hard reality of the present, and the romance-tinged memories of the past. Of course it is unnecessary to love the characters in a novel in order to see how they work together in their discrete universe and the big picture is what makes this novel work in its own way. Thanks to NetGalley and Random House for an advanced copy of this title in exchange for an honest ....more

author: O'Brien, Edna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is closer to three and a half stars, but doesn't quite hold together enough to get to four. It's a novel about violence against women that is pooThis is closer to three and a half stars, but doesn't quite hold together enough to get to four. It's a novel about violence against women that is poorly described on the back cover of my edition as: "When the euphoria of Willa's first love faded, it is replaced by bitterness..." This is NOT AT ALL what this book is about. Instead, it's a novel of repressed trauma and a willingness on the part of the protagonist to seek love after a fearful time in her life. It's also about another character who despises women and finally finds his way toward showing it. Somehow the book gets away with a lot of weirdness by the utter beauty of its writing. I'm reading O'Brien's works in chronological order with a friend and we're excited to see how her subjects evolve over time. ...more

title: Fatherland: A Memoir of War, Conscience, and Family Secrets
author: Bilger, Burkhard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sometimes family history lies hidden in the memories of the people who lived it and then do not speak of it. In the case of Burkhard Bilger, his curioSometimes family history lies hidden in the memories of the people who lived it and then do not speak of it. In the case of Burkhard Bilger, his curiosity and drive to find out more about his grandfather's role as a Nazi official during the terrible times of World War II took him to the Alsace area between France and Germany. From his research and dogged determination, he is able to write this fantastic memoir. Was his grandfather a despot or a pragmatic and compassionate man? Where were the facts, in stories told by villagers, in archives, in the accusations of a striving politician to enact revenge? All of this comes out in the telling, along with lots of interesting history of the area and its vacillating control by French and German rulers. I learned a lot about a piece of Europe and wartime that I had never heard of. Thanks to NetGalley and Random House for an advanced copy of this book in exchange for an honest ....more

review: Keri Blakinger was a moderately successful figure skater in high school but her ambitions were derailed by an escalating drug habit and all the demoraKeri Blakinger was a moderately successful figure skater in high school but her ambitions were derailed by an escalating drug habit and all the demoralizing things that come with it, including estrangement from her family, the need to turn to sex work and crime to fund the habit, and finally, a prison sentence. What makes this memoir a great read is that Blakinger is able to write honestly about those experiences and also capture the lonely time in the chaos of a prison system that's purpose is not rehabilitation but a steady dehumanization of the prisoners. Blakinger is able to quit taking drugs and finally find a way to deal with it all by becoming an advocacy journalist to expose the greatest inequities of our prison system. On top of it all, she is a good writer and isn't afraid to bare her darkest moments before things improve in her life. ...more

review: Three and a half stars.Divorce is hard. Divorce during the pandemic is hard. Divorce against your hope is hard. When a poet writes a memoir about divoThree and a half stars.Divorce is hard. Divorce during the pandemic is hard. Divorce against your hope is hard. When a poet writes a memoir about divorce and turns the chronological story into a deconstructed series of semi-prose poems and direct speeches to the reader and frequent forays into the craft of storytelling, the author sometimes feels at arms-length from the audience. There are even admonishing moments that, summed up, say "I am not telling you this part and why would you want to know, anyway." Fair enough. The skeleton of the marriage as it crumbles is there and enough of the hurt and anger the author experiences comes across. I'm not sure the form of it all is my speed. ...more

review: The stories in this collection are about Black families in the south. The characters are often coming of age or are young, figuring out how to navigatThe stories in this collection are about Black families in the south. The characters are often coming of age or are young, figuring out how to navigate uncomfortable family relationships and the disappointments doled out by the people closest to them. My favorite stories include "Family Museum of the Ancient Postcards" where a child's aunt tries to find love in her forties and chooses a man no one in the family can stand; "If You Hit Randolph County, You've Gone Too Far" where a woman's brother upends the family after getting arrested on a drug charge; "We Are Taking Only What We Need" where a young girl's father falls in love with a white girl and brings her home to babysit, and other stories of breakups, life as a customer service phonebank worker, being a Jehova's Witness and canvassing the neighborhood for new converts, and more. The author bring the stories to life through the voices of her characters. Reminiscent of The Secret Life of Church Ladies, we are invited in to live in the heads of the people inside the stories. ...more

title: The Keep
author: Egan, Jennifer*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've had this ebook since 2010. I think I tried to read it a couple of times but it seemed too convoluted and I put it aside. But in a recent By the BI've had this ebook since 2010. I think I tried to read it a couple of times but it seemed too convoluted and I put it aside. But in a recent By the Book, Rebecca Makkai answered the question What’s your favorite book no one else has heard of by saying: "It’s not that unknown, but everyone’s out here loving Jennifer Egan and somehow not reading 'The Keep,' her best and weirdest novel. She gets away with things no one has any right to get away with; that’s my favorite kind of book." And then a bunch of writers I like on Twitter talked about that response and raved about The Keep and I had a severe moment of Fear of Missing Out and so I saw that I owned the book already and I had no excuse not to try it again. And I wasn't disappointed.The pleasure of this short novel is the writing and the puzzles the story is presenting. The writing itself is lively and full of the energy of its characters as they strive and obsess and get into their own heads. And it all comes to a head near the end. So satisfying. I liked my time in this larger-than-life story nested in a story nested in a tragedy. The key to finishing is to release all expectations and word-sleuthing and just Let The Story Happen To You....more

review: This story flies by, is entertaining, and also brings the 1800s to life. Highly recommended.The Romantic is engrossing historical fiction and the lateThis story flies by, is entertaining, and also brings the 1800s to life. Highly recommended.The Romantic is engrossing historical fiction and the latest of William Boyd's whole-life novels that recounts the remarkable life of Cashel Ross. The frame story, set by an introduction by the author, posits that he, "WB" was given a packet of documents, drawings, diaries, and clippings that chronicle Ross's life (and a lot of the history of technological advances like train travel) starting in 1800 in Ireland.Ross has a questionable origin story and is impetuous, ruled by his heart and not always his intellect. He is also a lovable character and his adventures take him all over Europe and to the United States, introducing the reader to some real-life historical figures such as Mary Shelley and Byron, as well as lesser-known historical events. Ross is driven by a romantic entanglement that propels him from place to place, always looking for his first love in the faces of others. Boyd's writing, as ever, is full of detail and emotion. Much of the story is funny, though there are melancholy episodes as he hops from one profession to another, including being a soldier, an explorer, a farmer, and a diplomat.For readers who loved "Any Human Heart," this novel will satisfy that thirst for a strong central character and lots of historical detail.Thanks to Netgalley and Penguin books for an advance copy of this novel in exchange for a fair ....more

review: Generally, I have enjoyed Murakami's slow rollout of stories and their weird encounters between people (and occasionally, cats.) And there is an allurGenerally, I have enjoyed Murakami's slow rollout of stories and their weird encounters between people (and occasionally, cats.) And there is an alluring element in Norwegian Wood and the way the prose is written that weaves an enchanting pathway. Yet in this novel, there are sexually immature preoccupations and death fixations that the rest of the story can't overcome. And since this one didn't include much else in the way of plot (no cults, no double moons, no slow chopping of vegetables) it didn't work. It had too much teenage boy fantasy to lend itself to strong female characters, and has an unnecessarily enigmatic ending.*I did like the references to The Magic Mountain and its security of long sanitarium stays.**I do not recommend the audiobook. review: Three and a half stars.This novel has a bit of a Rachel Cusk vibe in that the unnamed protagonist writes in a emotionally detached way about her feeliThree and a half stars.This novel has a bit of a Rachel Cusk vibe in that the unnamed protagonist writes in a emotionally detached way about her feelings and experiences of maternity. She is a novelist and professor who teaches at an Iowa University (just like the author) and is in her later child-bearing years. She has suffered a miscarriage before she had a daughter. Mix in real-life elements like climate change, bioethics, Covid, and the severe threat to women's reproductive freedom and the novel becomes a direct examination of the state of our lives in the moment without allowing us to see anything beyond character's viewpoint. Mary Shelley becomes a touchstone for the narrator, both her life and the creation of the novel, Frankenstein. It's all somewhat claustrophobic with tiny moments of beauty mixed in. ...more

review: Forbidden Notebook is a novel set in post-war Italy and is in the form of a diary written by a 43-year-old woman who has cracked open her repressed feForbidden Notebook is a novel set in post-war Italy and is in the form of a diary written by a 43-year-old woman who has cracked open her repressed feelings and pours them into a forbidden journal. Over the six months of the journal, Valeria examines her life, the weaknesses of her children and husband, the severity of her own mother's judgment against her, and her abject loneliness in her role as a woman of the time. The author herself was a feminist anti-fascist who was arrested for her protests against the Italian government and who also kept diaries that later influenced other writers like Elena Ferrante. Though relatively short, this novel does at times feel like it bogs down in Valeria's indecision, but that is a slight criticism for a work that feels modern and chaotic....more

title: I Am Homeless If This Is Not My Home
author: Moore, Lorrie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At one point in this short novel, one character asks another, "Don't you like farce?" And I had to ask myself if the novel was telling me that what I'At one point in this short novel, one character asks another, "Don't you like farce?" And I had to ask myself if the novel was telling me that what I've been reading is farcical rather than a wrenching examination of griefs of all kinds. Because I think that's what I got out of it, around the slapstick dialog, a deep well of loneliness and loss. Finn is a late middle-aged teacher whose romantic partner Lily has been suicidal for a long time. The story is set right before the calamitous election of 2016, years before Covid, too, though I felt ghosts of oncoming loss from that terrible first year seep in through the prose, as well. Finn is visiting his dying brother in a hospice and gets word he must come home and deal with Lily. How much to give away here? I am not going into the plot, but it takes a bizarre turn from realism to what feels like a fevered dream of a road trip. And the OTHER part of the novel is a series of letters from the post-Civil War era from a boardinghouse owner to her sister, mostly about her troublesome tenant, a la Faulkner. I do not know that those parts of the story did anything for me but distract from Finn and Lily's swansong. There are some gorgeous passages that carried me along, but I'm still trying to figure out if there was something I missed. I love Lorrie Moore's short stories and wish this were more like those. Thanks to NetGalley and Knopf for an advanced  copy of this book in exchange for an honest . ...more

review: What I admire about Katherine Heiny's stories is that she writes characters with so much tenderness and humor that you just want to spend hours with tWhat I admire about Katherine Heiny's stories is that she writes characters with so much tenderness and humor that you just want to spend hours with them as they grapple with the everyday troubles of modern life. This collection of stories is about relationships in various forms: parents/children; divorced couples; co-workers. One of my favorite stories is about people who work at the DMV giving driving tests and how they choose which drivers go with which tester. Another is about an a small life adventure at an airport after all the flights have been cancelled. Every once in a while, there will be a sharp jolt of recognition by the character about the reality of existence. All this being said, there is a sameness to the emotional temperature of these stories that might blur them together in tone. But since it's a tone I like, that's okay with me. Thank you to Knopf and NetGalley for an advance  copy of this book in exchange for an honest ....more

title: Corinne
author: Morrow, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of the rare times when I just wanted to devour a novel as fast as possible. I stayed up way too late and then finished it this morning. HeThis is one of the rare times when I just wanted to devour a novel as fast as possible. I stayed up way too late and then finished it this morning. Here is what made this book so good:1. The writing. It's lively, honest, and the dialogue isn't stylized. 2. It grapples with moral issues revolving fundamental Christianity but isn't at all trying to preach anything other than love.3. The strong main character Corinne won't compromise her values but still wants to be loved and accepted by her family. Her love interest is frustrating in the best way--he is so torn over the way he was raised and his deep love for Corinne.4. It is sex-positive, meaning that there are explicit scenes that are loving and also erotic.5. The stridency of the families in this novel provide some understanding of how we are so divided, culturally, in this country.6. It is funny.7. Rebecca Morrow, who are you? I will read more of your novels (and I think maybe I've read a lot of your non-pseudonymous ones?)...more

review: This is an entertaining and self-deprecating account of Bob Odenkirk's career, from the tenuous beginnings of sketch comedy, through a middling middleThis is an entertaining and self-deprecating account of Bob Odenkirk's career, from the tenuous beginnings of sketch comedy, through a middling middle career, and finally, to his phenomenal success playing Saul Goodman and beyond. The book ends before the end of Better Call Saul and thus misses his heart attack. There is not a lot of personal revelation here, no deep dives into his emotions. But the book does manage to celebrate the rare feelings of joy when a show/movie/performance goes right, particularly if there's a strong sense of community with fellow actors, directors, and talent management. Thirty percent of this book is index, so the ending felt abrupt. He's a likeable guy and I didn't mind spending a few hours with him here....more

review: Using all her best character building talent and her exploration of emotion that she uses for her literary fiction, Curtis Sittenfeld has pivoted thisUsing all her best character building talent and her exploration of emotion that she uses for her literary fiction, Curtis Sittenfeld has pivoted this novel toward romance and created a nice tension between the tendency of the protagonist, Sally, to self-sabotage where love is concerned. Sally is a comedy writer on an SNL-like late night comedy show and this is where the story shines. I love workplace stories, and this lays out how the show is structured, some of the politics, and how the show's producer is odd and commanding without being (totally) a tryant. The guest host rock star Noah works with Sally on some sketches and they have chemistry. But Sally messes it up. Then Covid hits. There is sufficient conflict and lots of inner-turmoil; the characters shine through. I might prefer Sittenfeld's deep dives into the imagined lives of real people, but this was fun and fulfilling. Thanks so much to NetGalley and Doubleday for an advance  copy of this novel in exchange for an honest . ...more

review: A short novel that at its heart is about the pursuit of art as a way to live. The narrative is not easy nor free flowing. The protagonist relates a peA short novel that at its heart is about the pursuit of art as a way to live. The narrative is not easy nor free flowing. The protagonist relates a period where she is given leisure time (through a loveless marriage to a wealthy man) to practice writing. She is not interested in the commerce of writing and seems to have no will to publish, but because she is no longer a cleaner in an art gallery, she has all the free time and resources she requires to contemplate visual art and then write about what she sees. Her closest relationships are to other women, one of whom is a dancer, and another friend who goes with her to listen to music. Through painting, dance, and performance, the narrator finds in herself the ability to make a choice for her own life. ...more

author: Luiselli, Valeria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Four and a half stars."Best of" short story anthologies are generally comprised of work from a particular year that has been selected by the editor anFour and a half stars."Best of" short story anthologies are generally comprised of work from a particular year that has been selected by the editor and then narrowed to the stories that will be published by a guest judge. In this collection, however, the collection is highly curated by Valeria Luiselli and features specific themes, much of it about the beginnings of Covid, and highlights ten stories in translation from Spanish, Russian, Norwegian, Polish, Hebrew, Bengali, and Greek authors. There are surprises in mood and tone; a couple of the stories are absurdist and a couple of them are about writing and storytelling themselves. There is an amazing/puzzling/thrilling/grotesque long form story about two characters who meet during the fall of the Soviets (Horse Soup) that I'm not sure I completely understood but was riveted by. And there is new work by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie about ghosting and a Covid-set family story by Lorrie Moore. I am inspired to read more of some of these writers' works. This is one of the best anthologies I've read. ...more

Talty bringsFour and a half stars.These short stories comprise one big story, that of David and his family, members of the Penobscot Nation in Maine. Talty brings the characters to life by exploring all aspects of their family life, the addicted, proud, funny, loving moments of the mundane to the life-changing. The stories could stand alone, but for me were more affecting as they leap back and forth across time, leading to a climax and then a retrospective finality. I'll be thinking about this book for a long time and may someday revisit it to see how it all comes together once again....more

title: Newsroom Confidential: Lessons (and Worries) from an Ink-Stained Life
author: Sullivan, Margaret
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is about Margaret Sullivan's experiences in journalism over the course of her career. It's not comprehensive, rather, more an overview with This book is about Margaret Sullivan's experiences in journalism over the course of her career. It's not comprehensive, rather, more an overview with highlights of the behind the scenes discussions (or arguments) about how to present news fairly and whether objectivity can be a shared value in this fractious age. Sullivan relays the changes that have come to the profession with the advent of social media and of the deepening cultural divide in our country. I am drawn to books about the inner-workings of institutions and this is where this book excels. There isn't much gossip but we do get to know some of the people in power and the struggle to put out ethical stories pitted against profit. I would have liked more gossip, but that's not the author's purpose or style. The final section of the book is where Sullivan makes suggestions for saving our country and democracy and while it feels hopeful when reading the words, it's harder leave thinking everything is going to be okay.Thanks to NetGalley and St. Martin's Press for an advance  copy of this book in exchange for an honest ....more

review: I think I might be done with this series. So much of it is completely beyond belief. The murder mystery itself is fine and the war setting is interestI think I might be done with this series. So much of it is completely beyond belief. The murder mystery itself is fine and the war setting is interesting. But I'm annoyed that four books in, I do not have a handle on the relationship (if you can call it that) between Bess and Simon, her father's right-hand fellow spy. Bess seems to have NO emotions other than a drive to solve a mystery. She is blank slate beyond a standard affection for her parents, and yes, she is caring when it comes to the soldiers that she attends on the battlefield. The paternalism toward Bess from both her father and Simon is oppressive. Maybe I'll give it another go next year....more

review: This short novel satirizes the superficiality of our culture that commodifies wellness, feminism, and internet communities under the guise of self-carThis short novel satirizes the superficiality of our culture that commodifies wellness, feminism, and internet communities under the guise of self-care. In the story, two women, Maren and Devin, found a website to appeal to Millennials. It's a sort of send-up of Goop, with expensive serums and sex toys and other accessories to make women feel empowered through spending. The founders are at odds on many levels and when one of their angel investors is accused of sexual exploitation, Maren and Devin must reckon with the reality of the situation. The novel makes fun of the levels to which influencers will go to shape their lives in service to the content the audience demands. The author does a good job of making the characters distinct and conflicted; neither is fully a hero or villain. Three and a half stars for the abruptness of the ending....more

author: Barker, Pat
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is so much packed into this short novel that focuses on Rivers, a psychiatrist and anthropologist and Billy Prior, a soldier who had been RiversThere is so much packed into this short novel that focuses on Rivers, a psychiatrist and anthropologist and Billy Prior, a soldier who had been Rivers' patient in the first book in the Regeneration series. Prior desperately wants to return to battle after a stay in the hospital to treat his war trauma. He has a chance to work in an office in London but rejects that idea and goes back to France to fight with his regiment.In the meantime, Rivers continues to take care of war-torn patients and recall his visit to a group of native people in Melanesia. The narrative moves back and forth between Rivers in the past and present, and Billy Prior's experiences. There are shared themes and brutalities in each part. Barker's style is descriptive and portent with emotion. It is an indictment of war and colonialism, all about men in the throes of crisis: physical, spiritual, and emotional. This was nothing like I expected, a war novel about human misery and connection. The whole series is brilliant and this final volume pulls everything together. ...more

review: For readers looking for a long, languorous story that spans decades.I'm giving this novel the full enthusiasm of five stars. The characters, particulaFor readers looking for a long, languorous story that spans decades.I'm giving this novel the full enthusiasm of five stars. The characters, particularly the three characters the book is focused on, are drawn with such care. Agnes Lee, whom I consider the heart and soul of the book is in her eighties, a writer, and an unconventional woman who is unafraid to ruffle the sensibilities of her family and community. Her lifelong best friend, Polly, is always trying to do the right thing, and always giving everyone the benefit of the doubt, to her peril. They meet a young woman named Maud who is capable of injecting new life into what could be staid. The Maine setting, too, is essential, as is the land that generations ago was structured to be a protected land trust for families to visit and pass down as inheritance one generation to the next. So we've got what could be a formulaic family saga but it is much more. In spending so much time with the characters, we watch them struggle, and even in their old age, grow.It's best to go into this novel without knowing much. ...more

review: Ian McEwan has written a fantastic remembrance of modern life from the end of World War II to the present through the close point of view of Roland BaIan McEwan has written a fantastic remembrance of modern life from the end of World War II to the present through the close point of view of Roland Baines, an Englishman who led a fairly unremarkable life that was yet filled with deeply felt relationships with his parents, inlaws, lovers and wives, and his children. In the early part of the novel, his wife has abandoned him with an infant and few answers, and he must learn how to navigate that loss, which is mixed up with his conflicted feelings of another betrayal that happened when he was a teen. Baines is also affected by world events as they happen; Chernobyl, the fall of the Soviet Empire, and many more, but it's the personal that dominates the bulk of his observations, desires, and sorrows. This is a big ambitious novel that was well worth the time it takes to get fully absorbed into Baines' life.Thanks so much to NetGalley and Knopf for an advance  copy of this book in exchange for an honest ....more

review: Audrey Magee weaves together history and pathos in this novel about a remote Irish island who has two paying guests come in the summer to work. One isAudrey Magee weaves together history and pathos in this novel about a remote Irish island who has two paying guests come in the summer to work. One is a painter and the other a linguist with a lot of emotional baggage. It takes place in 1979 and the novel matter-of-factly recounts brutal murders between unionists and nationalists in an escalating cycle of mayhem. But that's not the bulk of the story, which is more personal and claustrophobic when it focuses on the island-bound subjects. The narrative easily passes off between four main characters and gives access to each one's stream of consciousness perspective revealing their motivations and capacity to hurt one another. Art, cultural identity, gender roles, and paternalism are major themes and it becomes clear who is deserving of sympathy as the tensions rise....more

review: Roddy Doyle reads his own book in the audio version of this short story collection written during the days of pandemic lockdown. All the characters inRoddy Doyle reads his own book in the audio version of this short story collection written during the days of pandemic lockdown. All the characters in the stories are middle-aged parents, mostly fathers, who find themselves shut off from the world starting in March 2020. Some couples use the opportunity to grow closer, and some to break off from tired relationships. One man suffers from a panic attack and remembers something hard from his childhood. One father decides to break curfew and go find his drug-addicted son in Dublin. Doyle is the perfect narrator for these stories; I could listen to him all day long. It is possible that readers might not want to look back so soon at the moments when we didn't know what to expect from global catastrophe. But it feels somehow familiar, comforting. And now I want to go back and read Doyle's whole body of work, many titles I've missed among favorites like The Commitments and The Woman Who Walked Into Doors....more

title: Virginia Woolf's Mrs Dalloway: Bookmarked
author: Black, Robin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is a lot packed into this deep dive into Virginia Woolf's novel, Mrs. Dalloway. Robin Black, herself a novelist and short fiction author, examinThere is a lot packed into this deep dive into Virginia Woolf's novel, Mrs. Dalloway. Robin Black, herself a novelist and short fiction author, examines the craft in this long-revered classic. But she goes beyond just how the novel was written. She is able to describe how she interprets Mrs. Dalloway down to the bones of the sentence level and what is possibly left out of the narrative and why. Why is Septimus Smith featured in the novel? Is it okay to be bored by Clarissa's daughter, Elizabeth, and why might that be? Why do readers get so hung up and judgmental about the depiction of mothers in Woolf's and in Black's work? There is a tension here between reading and writing and living, and what it did for me is to remind me how much I enjoy thinking about it on different levels: how/when/where/why we read. Black's analysis is tender, smart, and funny. ...more

review: In this third novel in the voice of Lucy Barton, Lucy is spirited away from the beginnings of Covid in New York to rural Maine to wait things out withIn this third novel in the voice of Lucy Barton, Lucy is spirited away from the beginnings of Covid in New York to rural Maine to wait things out with her ex-husband William. They had reconnected (the story of which was recounted in "Oh William") and he told her that he wanted to save her life. And so we hear Lucy recount what happened over that first year, good and bad things that were happening to people they loved and remembering other things that had affected her life. She captures the uncertainty and disorientation of the pandemic and also the deep political divide that widened in America. Lucy is here in this story as it reaches out and asks for empathy and acceptance, to confront the past and figure out a way to move ahead. Readers who were invested in Lucy's story in the first two novels (and some appearances in "Anything Can Happen") will want to see what happens in a time that is so recent and yet feels far away. And there may be readers who didn't meet Lucy in previous novels who will be able to connect with her here in "Lucy By the Sea." It is a book I will come back to.Thanks to Random House and NetGalley for an advanced copy of this book in exchange for an honest ....more

review: This novel is at this point in 2022 the best one I've read so far. It is historical fiction about two of Charles Dickens' sons who are sent off to AusThis novel is at this point in 2022 the best one I've read so far. It is historical fiction about two of Charles Dickens' sons who are sent off to Australia to make their own lives in the world of sheep ranching. The first person narrator, Edward "Plorn" Dickens, is the youngest child of ten and Keneally has imbued him with emotional sensitivity and youthful exuberance as he arrives in the colony right before he turns seventeen. So it's both a coming of age novel and a fish out of water story, with the added benefit of Plorn's ambivalence in being a Dickens son who has yet to read any of his father's novels. Everywhere he goes, people quote their favorite passages and recount their favorite characters in the Dickens oeuvre, and young Plorn has to pretend to go along. The novel brings the bushland to life and doesn't neglect to address the harms done to Australia's native people under the strong arm of Britain. It's funny in the Dickensian sense and a novel I couldn't wait to return to. Excellent all around. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is not one wasted word in this novella about a mother's quest to find out more about the death of her daughter. The narrative centers around EleThere is not one wasted word in this novella about a mother's quest to find out more about the death of her daughter. The narrative centers around Elena, who, in her sixties, has Parkinson's Disease and has decided to take a trip across the city to recruit a helper in her investigation. In this story, we see the excruciating process for Elena to take medication, wait for it to kick in, then travel by bus and cab on her trip. She can see the world only from the waist down and as she moves, she remembers moments from the past and discussions she's had with her now-deceased daughter. The lives of three women unfold as Elena reaches her destination. So good! But it's brutal and no one is spared from examination, including a powerful patriarchal society that makes rules for women that force them to submit. As of this reading, this novella is on the short list for the International Booker Prize. ...more

title: Run Towards the Danger: Confrontations with a Body of Memory
author: Polley, Sarah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: These personal essays relate periods in Sarah Polley's life where she felt out of control. These outside forces were pressures put on her by her parenThese personal essays relate periods in Sarah Polley's life where she felt out of control. These outside forces were pressures put on her by her parents, colleagues in her acting life, and/or her own body. There is also an essay grappling with sexual assault. And the final essay that deals with a concussive brain injury and the various treatments she tried. And there are other things she discusses that could seem like a laundry list of ailments but instead come together to show a person's life. In these raw and tender accounts, Polley investigates her responses to these pressures and the crippling anxiety that came with some of them. It's a book I am sorry to see end....more

title: Only Happiness Here: In Search of Elizabeth von Arnim
author: Carey, Gabrielle
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: More like 2.5 stars.This strange book is a hybrid of the author's vague "project" to find happiness after some miserable things happen to her by examiMore like 2.5 stars.This strange book is a hybrid of the author's vague "project" to find happiness after some miserable things happen to her by examining the life of Elizabeth von Arnim. So it succeeds in getting a reader like me interested in von Arnim's life and work. Von Arnim was a wildly successful novelist who (seemingly) weaves her own life into her books. The author of this memoir, Gabrielle Carey, however, projects her own life events onto the ones in von Arnim's, with flimsy analysis and specious, vapid proclamations. One of the most egregious is that von Arnim couldn't have been depressed/unhappy during a particular point in her life because it was then that she wrote her most happy novel. I'm glad I read it and want to know more about the von Arnim circle of friends/lovers like HG Wells and the Russell brothers and other literary luminaries of the time, but this book could have been so much more in its execution. ...more

review: Three and a half stars. As gripping as Walter Mosley's writing is, the world where Leonid McGill dwells is the darkest, most vile society of ruthless Three and a half stars. As gripping as Walter Mosley's writing is, the world where Leonid McGill dwells is the darkest, most vile society of ruthless scions, felons, pimps, serial killlers, high-tech wizards, and precocious teenage sons and where it's hard as a reader to keep bearings. McGill knows everyone, has access to remarkable tools of surveillance, hidden lairs, emergency hotlines, and more. He lives as if he's doomed, and he probably is. It's a faced-paced story here in this second of a series. Become I come back to McGill world, I think I'd like to try some Mosley's other detectives and see what they are up to....more

review: This is a difficult novel to , so I'll instead give some impressions about what is a complicated, absurdist, political, cultural story about a gThis is a difficult novel to , so I'll instead give some impressions about what is a complicated, absurdist, political, cultural story about a generation of Icelandic people in the early 1900s eking out an existence in a harsh landscape, trying to raise goats to survive. Overall, it's an incredible novel highlighting our need for love and our inevitable folly. 1. The novel's main character, Bjartur, is selfish, lacking empathy, and misogynistic but has such a fool-like nature that it's impossible to despise him despite his flaws. His refusal to listen to anyone else in regard to anything leads to many tragic events.2. There are incredible passages of beauty and wonder. 3. Other characters in the novel, notably Bjartur's children, are nuanced and individual. The eldest daughter, Asta, is established early on as a dreamer thwarted by her place in their society. 4. Some long passages about local politics and the economy are hard to sit through.5. The light tone of this novel reminds me of The Saga of Gosta Berling. ...more

title: Ancestor Trouble: A Reckoning and a Reconciliation
author: Newton, Maud*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: ANCESTOR TROUBLE is a combination of a deeply personal account of Maud Newton's investigation into her own family history and a broader look at the waANCESTOR TROUBLE is a combination of a deeply personal account of Maud Newton's investigation into her own family history and a broader look at the ways humans have tried to connect or disconnect from their ancestors. In this examination, she conveys her sincere desire to question and understand her parents for their toxic beliefs about race and religion, and for actions her parents took that did actual harm to their children. Newton's colorful extended family is part of the subject of inquiry, the good and not so good. And she makes a case for what tendencies, physical and emotional, she might have inherited.Newton also discusses genetics and some of the theories of genetic trauma that might be ensconced in brains decades or even centuries later, patterns of behavior that are sometimes repeated, and, finally, a real effort to connect to ancestors through guided meditation. This attempt to communicate with spirits is one of my favorite parts of the book; whether there was something "there" or it was a product of her mind doesn't much matter to me. I liked hearing about the experiences the intentions behind them.Readers are sure to consider their own family histories and how to perhaps forgive past generations for terribly wrongs. It's a fascinating look at how we might connect to our own familial past.Thanks to NetGalley for an advanced  copy of this fabulous book....more

While I enjoyed the reading experience, I have to admit that a lot of my satisfaction came from making connections between the text of The Candy House and its predecessor, A Visit from the Goon Squad. review: This novella turns out to be a small wonder of the claustrophobia of a small Irish 1985-era town where the protagonist, Bill Furlong, follows the routThis novella turns out to be a small wonder of the claustrophobia of a small Irish 1985-era town where the protagonist, Bill Furlong, follows the routines of his fuel delivery business and the family rituals involved in celebrating the Christmas season. He chafes under the constraints put upon him by his roles within the community and he's forced through circumstance to confront the past and present. This story's writing has prose that is reminiscent of Joyce and Colm Toibin and Edna O'Brien, plainspoken yet also so full of observation and emotion. Furlong loves his family deeply but cannot escape his unease in a town that may never fully accept him as he is. ...more

review: Aaargh! I am torn about how I feel after having finished this novel, 85% of which I couldn't stop reading. But that last 15% was an enormous struggle Aaargh! I am torn about how I feel after having finished this novel, 85% of which I couldn't stop reading. But that last 15% was an enormous struggle to finally limp to the end. The nine narrators of this upside down two days in hot Norway are well defined and I was able to keep them all apart in my mind. Theirs are the mundane lives and worries of people. Boredom, frustration with spouses and children, aging parents, and some mental illness are all things to contend with. Knausgard adds in elements of a looming apocalypse and the characters in varying degrees either underreact or completely rationalize the irrational events taking place, and I'm still invested. It all feels close to home and our current circumstance with adjusting to or suffering from the pandemic and our democracy slipping away. We live our lives as best we can and try to ignore/stay numb or wonder what we can possibly do to make things better? What is death? What is living? Who can say?I read that there is another part coming to this new series and so yes, even with my hesitancy to recommend a book with a suffocating final chapter, I'll want to see what comes next. And the autofiction Knausgard has written is on my future books to read list....more

review: This emotional novel contains a deeper understanding of the narrator Lucy Barton's inner life and her relationship to her now-deceased mother in law, This emotional novel contains a deeper understanding of the narrator Lucy Barton's inner life and her relationship to her now-deceased mother in law, her two husbands, and her daughters. Lucy's first husband William comes to her to talk, confide in, and rely on as he faces his own aging and its catastrophes. As in the first novel, "My Name is Lucy Barton," Lucy is the sole voice here and so it is through her radiance and anxieties and traumas that we see her world and the people in it. A reader need not have read the first in the series, but together they make up a heartbreaking pair of novels that I will return to again and again. "Oh, William" is highly recommended to readers who enjoy quiet novels where plot is not the driving force.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for an advanced copy of this fine novel....more

title: Smile: The Story of a Face
author: Ruhl, Sarah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When playwright Sarah Ruhl gave birth to twins after a difficult pregnancy, something happened and she developed Bells Palsy, a condition that foreverWhen playwright Sarah Ruhl gave birth to twins after a difficult pregnancy, something happened and she developed Bells Palsy, a condition that forever changes her self-perception and the way she feels comfortable confronting the world. This memoir discusses that journey. What sets it apart from similar stories is her curiosity and engagement with the wider world. She has a successful career in the arts and must work diligently to keep producing art while taking care of babies and her own health. And so she asks what does a smile mean, anyway? Why must a woman be expected to smile in every circumstance? Will her babies be alienated from a mother who can't beam down at them with a loving face? And beyond sociology, Ruhl must also navigate a complicated medical system that doesn't know how to go about treating her. Both sorrow and a nod to the absurdist situation this condition has brought to her are here in the story. And it might be a sort of path for others in similar circumstances to follow. This memoir is excellent and recommended. Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for an advanced copy of this lovely book....more

review: There were parts of this Covid/Grief/Actor memoir I liked, but the good did not outweigh the less good. Cecily Strong, one of my favorite SNL players,There were parts of this Covid/Grief/Actor memoir I liked, but the good did not outweigh the less good. Cecily Strong, one of my favorite SNL players, lost a beloved cousin to cancer right before the start of the shutdown of the country and because of her long-term depression and anxiety and her rational fears, she has a hard time dealing with everything. She moves to an upstate New York rental and starts writing scraps of thoughts (letters to her deceased cousin, to her estranged boyfriend, her younger self) and pieces together memories of those thoughts with texts and emails. It's all kind of a mess and maybe that was intended to echo the chaos of those months for everyone. But that randomness isn't necessarily especially interesting to read. When stories of her past peek through, it's compelling. Strong's grieving process is so personal that it somehow feels intrusive to have stumbled upon it....more

review: Taken solely as a standalone novel, Sea of Tranquility is well plotted and full of Mandel's brilliant scene setting that brings her worlds to life. ItTaken solely as a standalone novel, Sea of Tranquility is well plotted and full of Mandel's brilliant scene setting that brings her worlds to life. It's a time travel novel where its chronologies twist upon themselves and come to a satisfying conclusion. But the larger Mandellian universe becomes more complicated and mind-bending when her previous novel, The Glass Hotel, comes into play. Characters from that novel are also centered in this one. How does the time travel affect the outcome of the the first? Furthermore, there are pandemics in this novel and in Station Eleven, but are those universes connected? And how much of OUR real pandemic experiences influenced this novel? So much to consider!Part of the fun of understanding Sea of Tranquility is in trying to keep all the pieces straight, which might not be fun for every reader. Because I've long been a fan of Mandel's novels, I appreciated the work she took in carefully constructing the story and kept an open mind about what she is trying to accomplish....more

review: Three and a half stars. There are parts of this novel that are relatable if you angry about the state of our country (minus the pandemic since this waThree and a half stars. There are parts of this novel that are relatable if you angry about the state of our country (minus the pandemic since this was written before it happened) and beyond terrified about the catastrophes that are all around us, coming fast and hot. The main character of Wayward is so angry and frazzled that she impulsively buys a dilapidated house in a poor neighborhood in Syracuse and leaves her husband and high school age daughter to live there. What happens beyond that, Sam's new friends, her paring down of everything, her broken connection to her daughter, add up to less than a reader might expect of a novel that is almost all about her. A character certainly doesn't have to be likable. But she can be evaluated based on how well her motivations are articulated and enacted. Maybe that's the analogy, that none of us, no matter how much we'd like to be able to influence our futures for the better, have agency or an ability to do that. And it hurts to think about. The novel has to be given credit for the discussion....more

review: As ever, I enjoy King's writing and the way she builds specificity into characters and setting. There are two standout stories in this collection. "WhAs ever, I enjoy King's writing and the way she builds specificity into characters and setting. There are two standout stories in this collection. "When in the Dordogne" is a coming of age story about a teenage boy whose parents go away for eight weeks in the summer so the father can heal from his mid-life crisis. They hire two young men to watch the teen and the unstructured time opens up doors into the wider world for him, with no menace. It's a tender story and as is typical for King, full of humor. The other story I loved is called "Timeline." A woman who has just broken up with her boyfriend moves in with her brother and his girlfriend, who has a drinking problem. The sister gets a job in a restaurant and makes new friends. The story is funny and heartfelt. And the affection between characters is warm. ...more

author: Maugham, W. Somerset
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You can't talk about this novel and how good some of it is without first acknowledging that its (author's? characters'? society's) depictions and consYou can't talk about this novel and how good some of it is without first acknowledging that its (author's? characters'? society's) depictions and considerations of Chinese people are terrible. Throughout the novel, just ONE character who is Chinese is called by name; the rest are lumped together with adjectives like: inhuman, gross, etc. So that's an undeniable part of the story and it's hard to read. The exoticism and out and out racism serve to show how blatantly white people were and still are as colonialists. In between the condescension and insults, there is a wonderful individual story about a woman named Kitty and her own dawning realization that she is not a good person but would like to be. Kitty has been raised by another not-good person, her mother, and has been taught that a good marriage to any man of means is Kitty's sole reason for living. And when that doesn't pan out and she settles for someone she can barely stand, their destinies are set. On top of everything else, this novel has a cholera epidemic. Because, of course it does. Epidemics are endemic. ...more

review: Three and a half stars. I was heavily invested in the main character Nella as she brought her life as a Black assistant in predominantly white publishThree and a half stars. I was heavily invested in the main character Nella as she brought her life as a Black assistant in predominantly white publishing house to the reader. Nella is smart, engaging, and full of ambition. So the novel excels in building a world where culture and discomfort from being the only Black person in a white space (and the big power imbalance that's built in) raises questions about how authentic can you be if everyone's weighing everything you say and do and comparing it to the status quo. Where the novel doesn't work as well comes later, where the plot takes a turn that throws things upside down and does not feel authentic to the story. Friendship, code switching, and cultural expectations would be good fodder for a bookclub discussion. ...more

author: White, Heather Cass
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is part meditation, part literary criticism, and part defense of the reading life as self-building. The writing is deft, and the structure iThis book is part meditation, part literary criticism, and part defense of the reading life as self-building. The writing is deft, and the structure is unconventional. Cass White starts with some assertions about the reading life in general and then goes on to a deeper analysis that uses literary works to back up her thesis. This was the strongest part of the book, looking at how reading is transgressive and an act of self-containment that rebels against the forces that would control us. She uses (among others) Dorothea Brooke and Frankenstein's monster as demonstrations of the power reading has to expand, instruct, and possibly disappoint, and has an especially rich analysis of some of Elizabeth Bishop's poetry. Cass White also makes it clear that reading in and of itself is not morally superior to any other pursuit, yet how for some people there's a pull to depart from the immediacy of the present and enter the state of reading that can be akin to dreaming. It's an excellent thought experiment.Thanks to NetGalley for an advanced  copy of this book....more

The women have come together at a Sikh center to learn writing. The protagonist is a young woman named Nikki who is trying to find her place in the world, one step in and one step out of her culture. Rather than focus on learning to write, the women start telling erotic stories that are transcribed and shared. On top of all this is a mystery about the suicide and the menacing young men who make patrols around the area to keep women in line. review: The first and second novels of this trilogy follow Caithleen (Kate) from girlhood to her late teens as she observes her family life in the country as The first and second novels of this trilogy follow Caithleen (Kate) from girlhood to her late teens as she observes her family life in the country as part of a poor family and slowly awakens to the joys and pains of life. She has a best friend named Baba who bullies Kate, and though she's bratty and brazen, Baba also provides Kate over the course of years with a stable and loving friend. Kate's father is a mean alcoholic and her mother is kind but weak. As the family breaks apart and Kate is first sent off to convent school and then tries to start an adult life in Dublin, she is always aware of natural beauty and the humanity inside odd and difficult people. Her love life takes over and things take a turn. She is initiated into adult behavior and falls in love with an older man and matures.But the third novel is a whiplashed departure from the tenderness of the first two. And because the point of view switches from first person to third (and some chapters from Baba's perspective), Kate's strong voice and ways of seeing the world are lost. As her character recedes into the narrative, so do her chances for happiness.As a whole, the three novels are beautiful and full of empathy for their characters. The novels were considered scandalous by Irish society and the Church, unsurprisingly, because O'Brien's stories prick the secretive oppressions of life during that post-War time and show what it was like for women. (I did not much like the epilogue, written in the 1980s.)...more

title: The Scent Keeper
author: Bauermeister, Erica*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Two and a half stars. This novel is an example of starting with what might seem to be an intriguing idea/image and then shoehorning in a story to makeTwo and a half stars. This novel is an example of starting with what might seem to be an intriguing idea/image and then shoehorning in a story to make it fit. A child and her extremely evasive father live together on an island and he trains her to learn how to smell things because scents are SO important that he casts away his life to commit to preserving scents via a machine, and their isolation and his refusal to talk about anything else gives her no other context for thinking or living. He calls her "Little Lark" as a term of endearment and it feels so cloying.The narrative pounds the scent/smelling concept into every encounter. The child has almost no personality or inner life other than how sense memory (stimulated by scent) affects every thought and personal encounter. It's written in the tenor of a fairy tale or fable, which keeps the reader far, far away from the possibility of accepting the story as a realistic portrayal of the protagonist's coming of age. When she does finally get off the island, she has difficulties adjusting. The novel reminds me of How the Crawdads Sing and The Language of Flowers, and since I didn't like either of those books for similar reasons, this one doesn't fare any better. I'm not giving it a star rating to feed the algorithm because my motive isn't to trash the book. Some people obviously liked it a lot. ...more

review: Four and a half stars.This trio of novels is about a rushed marriage of a young British couple who barely know each other and have gone to Bucharest iFour and a half stars.This trio of novels is about a rushed marriage of a young British couple who barely know each other and have gone to Bucharest in 1939 so that the husband, Guy, can teach English. His wife Harriet has some romantic notion of what their marriage will be like and finds her expectations to be upended due to Guy's personality, the pressures of an impending war, and her loneliness. There's so much more here than the core relationship. A colorful cast of secondary characters surround the Pringles, sometimes friends and sometimes not. The gamut of human behavior and emotions are in these pages; there are no real heroes. But nonetheless, it was impossible to read almost a thousand pages of these novels and not feel a real loss when it is finished. ...more

review: Amma, a feminist playwright, is the central character of this novel, with each chapter featuring a new character who is somehow related to another of Amma, a feminist playwright, is the central character of this novel, with each chapter featuring a new character who is somehow related to another of the characters. Amma has finally been accepted by a mainstream theater group and is showcasing her feminist play about Amazonian women. Old friends and family gather to watch and celebrate Amma’s career. The rest of the book is about the histories of her friends, foes, and offspring. This is not a plot-driven novel. Instead, it is formatted as close-omniscient chapters in the “voices” of the featured characters. Young, old, middle-brow, activists, gay and straight and non-binary: The novel’s characters express the desires and disappointments of being outside the patriarchal system of British life over a century. The best chapters were those of Amma’s daughter, Yazz, and the final chapters in the book telling the stories of Grace and her daughter, Hattie. Least successful is the chapter about Amma's ex-husband. His inclusion feels like an afterthought compared with the rich detail we get about the other characters' lives.Having so many viewpoints and stories in this novel are meant to show that Black British (mostly) women are not a monolith. There are many personalities, obstacles, faults, and talents. The novel shows that life is never easy, that there are many forces than can inhibit progress and success, whatever that might mean....more

review: Three and a half stars, rounded up. A (slightly unsatisfying) meditation on the question: What are women for? Adam Bede and his brother, Seth, must caThree and a half stars, rounded up. A (slightly unsatisfying) meditation on the question: What are women for? Adam Bede and his brother, Seth, must care for their ailing mother and find enough work to support their small family. Both fall in love with women unable to love them back. Rivalry, religion, the role of women at home and outside the home, what happens when moral codes are broken and when landowners have dominion over their tenants; all of these ideas come together in the tale of this small community in rural England. Here, men are generally given the benefit of the doubt and women who stray in the least are scrutinized until they prove themselves pure of heart. There are many things to think about in terms of the subjects, themes, and tone. The deepest emotional connections come from the two women at the core of the narrative, Hetty and Dinah. Spoiler for the very end: Gut punch....more

review: In the vein of other startup novels like The Circle and startup memoirs like Uncanny Valley, Black Buck is a satirical startup novel viewed through thIn the vein of other startup novels like The Circle and startup memoirs like Uncanny Valley, Black Buck is a satirical startup novel viewed through the prism of race. Darren, a 22-year-old barista (hence his corporate-bestowed nickname, Buck) is lured from the easy life of coffee service to the cult-like hell of a startup that is "disrupting" counseling services. The company, Sumwun, sells corporations on zoom-based counseling for employees. But what Darren endures during his training goes well beyond the fervor of company pride and he is subjected to blatant aggressions as the sole Black employee of the company. And what follows is life-changing for Darren and everyone he knows. The plot is propulsive and lightning-fast, raising the melodrama and satire level. Readers are asked to examine their own biases and must also suspend disbelief to get to the end. Overall, Black Buck examines the ideas of saleship and adherence to personal, tribal, and corporate allegiances. Buck's relationships are mostly superficial, though he seems to yearn for more....more

review: Reading NOS4A2 took me back to my teenage years when I would anxiously wait for Stephen King to come out with scary novels. He obliged by publishing tReading NOS4A2 took me back to my teenage years when I would anxiously wait for Stephen King to come out with scary novels. He obliged by publishing them regularly, and for a number of years, I read them as quickly as I could. After Pet Sematary, however, I'd had my fill. It was just TOO gruesome for me and I started reading more of other stuff. Now, in 2020, I had the chance to buddy read this novel with a booktube friend and all the things I used to like in King's novels was here. Joe Hill does a good job of setting up tense scenarios and building mostly-believable characters to pull us from the beginning of the work to the end. His writing is packed with colorful descriptions, never skimping on the gore or perversity a story like this can require. There were nods to other books: a beloved Saint Bernard pet, undead children, a possessed car, a distressed teenage girl. And there was even a tiny homage to the DeZoet family from David Mitchell novels, a little Easter egg for an observant reader.There were some questionable moments, including the scope of the violence inflicted on the main character, Vic, that even for a horror novel seemed over the top. And maybe it didn't have to be quite as long? But those are small complaints; overall, it was a scary/fun/timely read. ...more

review: Three and a half stars. A sad but ultimately hopeful memoir about a woman with a severe eating disorder that develops in her teens and will probably nThree and a half stars. A sad but ultimately hopeful memoir about a woman with a severe eating disorder that develops in her teens and will probably never completely loosen its grip on her psyche. Susan Burton's relationship to eating swung from anorexia to bingeing and back. She writes colorfully and honestly about her attachment to controlled and uncontrolled consumption of food. There was in the story an overabundance of detail about her life in Boulder (and I say that as a Colorado native who is familiar with everything she's writing about), the names of the streets and stores that might not have been necessary, stretching out the story. But all in all it's a strong memoir about addiction and steps toward recovery and "normal" life, whatever that may be....more

Maggie Tulliver is as strong a character as Dorothea Brooks is in Middlemarch, and Maggie's brother Tom is as obstinate and unwaveringly dull as Mr. Casaubon. review: This delightfully deft book about William Shakespeare is an excellent introduction and overview to the messy labyrinth of what is known and unknown abThis delightfully deft book about William Shakespeare is an excellent introduction and overview to the messy labyrinth of what is known and unknown about the life of the playwright, poet, and citizen. Bill Bryson seems to have had a lot of fun researching both the man and the work, trying his best to separate absolute fact (hard to verify) and fictions invented for various purposes. Of particular interest to me is the section about publication of the plays after Shakespeare's death, the careful (and not so careful) corrections to manuscripts and the physical process of setting the type, and then all the frauds and thieves and Shakespeare-deniers. For anyone who is curious about WS's biography and what the world was like when he was alive, this book is the perfect pool in which to dip a toe.PS-Reading this book about the life/unknowns of WS made me even more appreciative of Maggie O'Farrell's Hamnet because it's clear she did her research and then imagined what might fill the gaps of the family's life that are undocumented, and what she came up seems so plausible and human. title: How Fiction Works

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What I love about this book is that it took me back to the days of college when I spent an inordinate amount of time close reading texts so I could wrWhat I love about this book is that it took me back to the days of college when I spent an inordinate amount of time close reading texts so I could write papers about them and (with some luck) say anything new about books written decades and even centuries earlier. James Wood's discourse is easy to follow, and it's clear that his conclusions are the basis for his life ing other writers' work. He talks about point of view and free indirect style. He talks about the purpose of fiction, art, and the artifices of realism. But at the very core--and it reaffirmed something important for me in terms of my own views of the worth of fiction--pleasure is attained when a reader can identify what Henry James calls "a blue river of truth curling" through fiction. And then as he has done throughout, Wood provides passages that exemplify what he is talking about. So I recommend this to readers who feel they might benefit from some reminders of why and how this whole fiction thing works on a textual level....more

It's about a woman in her early forties raising a son alone and working as a ghost writer for prominent personalities, though that work is not lucrative enough to pay the rent and childcare. So it's about economic instability and has a lot of other social issues packed into the story. How to raise empathetic sons, the me-too movement, the deep grief of seeing DJT elected into office, conflicts between mothers and daughters, and more. It did at times have a lecturing quality that rankled me even though I agree with about 90% of the lessons. All in all, it was an easy read.
