title: In the Darkroom
author: Faludi, Susan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A fulfilling dual memoir: Susan Faludi writes about her transgender father's life and how she (Faludi's father before the decision to identify publiclA fulfilling dual memoir: Susan Faludi writes about her transgender father's life and how she (Faludi's father before the decision to identify publicly as a woman) crafted her own persona as survival mechanism during the Holocaust. It's also a history of Hungary and its cruel treatment and eradication of its Jewish citizens throughout the lead-up and duration of World War II, and of the resurgence of violence spurred by homophobia and Antisemitism in the present. The psychology of identity, both as mob-think and self-expression of gender, are the book's focus. But familial memory and forgiveness are central, as well.There's much to parse in this sometimes infuriating relationship between father and daughter, who were estranged for many years and reconciled late in Faludi's middle age. The political becomes personal and shapes the lives of everyone involved....more

First, I knew who the killer was from the beginning, and second, I couldn't separate the actors from the characters in the book. But Lehane is good at making you know what motivates his characters' actions and the socio-economics that can't help but color what's going on. review: This novel ended up being a 3-star read for me. Where I've was completely taken with Millet's trilogy (How the Dead Dream; Ghost Lights; and Magnificence), Sweet Lamb of Heaven seems more metaphorical of our own precarious, teetering existence and less a novel about "real" characters, or predicaments that could, at least, be real. I do appreciate how much thought Millet puts into the themes and morality of her work; I can't get away without thinking a lot about what's she's fortelling. But. One of the pitfalls of refusing to know much (if anything) about a book is that sometimes I don't know I'm not in the mood for its subject matter until I get to it. review: I have normal reading experiences where I am engaged with a book and happily going through the pages or the screens till I get to the end, sometimes dI have normal reading experiences where I am engaged with a book and happily going through the pages or the screens till I get to the end, sometimes distracted or sometimes wishing the end would come sooner so I could move on to something else that's waiting on a shelf. But with The Round House, I experienced a rare jolt of pleasure that sustained itself from the first page to the last. Erdrich's electric prose, her very careful building of character, plot, setting, and most of all, rich emotion: these separate pieces of writing craft come together to tell Joe's story. I'm not going to say anything about what's inside, but if you want to be pulled deeply into the narration and feel Joe's joys and sorrows as you read along, try this one....more

review: There is much to admire in this memoir, which covers so much more than one woman and her goshawk. It's rich with stories about other falconers, writerThere is much to admire in this memoir, which covers so much more than one woman and her goshawk. It's rich with stories about other falconers, writers, the ethics of landscape worship, childhood habits of immersion in arcane subjects, and more. I did struggle sometimes with losing the track of the narrative if I tried to read too much in one sitting, a fault of my own and not the book's. The language is dense with imagery and the action of the goshawk's flight, and when I became impatient to find the threads of the author's story, my eyes would skip vast swaths of words. Then I would stop and go back a page or two to reassert my concentration. I could never be a falconer, but I enjoyed stepping into this very specific world where humans and animals bond tightly....more

title: Zero K
author: DeLillo, Don
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** Three and a half stars.Don Delillo's 21st century novels are more like meditations on themes rather than attempts to live up to his **spoiler alert** Three and a half stars.Don Delillo's 21st century novels are more like meditations on themes rather than attempts to live up to his greatest novel, Underworld. In Zero K, we meditate on the privilege of choosing to die and perhaps be resurrected in a post-human world, rather than to succumb to a basic run of the mill death from disaster, war, or disease, which the ethos of the novel assumes is imminent. So here, billionaires form a sort of cult around this dream of a tomorrow yet to come. But their gambit depends on the continued care and maintenance of their eerie, watery suspensions, which is like gambling on the honesty of timeshare sales people or the Church of Scientology. In this book, a billionaire's restless son witnesses his father's Quixotic attempt to command the future, and in seeing it up close, rejects the pursuit. While the whole book is well-written and philosophical, I was ready for it to be done a few chapters before we came to the end.**The blurb for this book says of it, "The wisest, richest, funniest, and most moving novel in years..." and I would say this book isn't funny in the least. title: My Name Is Lucy Barton        (Amgash #1)
author: Strout, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 2021: I reread this novel over the last couple of days in anticipation of the third installment of the Lucy Barton books, which is called Oh, William,2021: I reread this novel over the last couple of days in anticipation of the third installment of the Lucy Barton books, which is called Oh, William, about Lucy's first husband. I still haven't read the second and that's coming next. But I wanted to get in the mood first. I noticed that several times Lucy mentions that this "isn't the story of her marriage" to William. I paid a lot of attention to the times she talks about him, his chilly relationship to her parents, who hate him for his airs and because he lives in New York. So those details are on my mind. I still cried at the same part I cried at the first two times I read this, when Lucy's father humiliates her brother in front of the town for being gay in a spectacularly cruel way. It hurt so much to think of this scene. With this third time reading, I noticed how many characters are suffering from the aftermath of traumas and so humbled by kindnesses from teachers and strangers and friends. And at how deeply Lucy forgave her flawed, incapable parents. 2017: Probably one of the saddest, most revealing novels I've read. It's on the same level as William Maxwell's So Long, See You Tomorrow. There's no great mystery about what this novel is. Lucy Barton is not an unreliable narrator; she's a narrator who sees clearly how she became who she is. She is acknowledging the severe disappointments of life and the pain and beauty of relationships and love. She is asking to be seen, to be allowed to know and say her own name. Now I'm going on to read the companion novel Anything is Possible. 2016: This brief novel unwinds slowly. For me, it pulled up feelings about childhood and then later, aging and marriage, so strongly. The narrator, Lucy, show how people still love, even through terrible pasts....more

title: The Hotel New Hampshire
author: Irving, John*

review: 9/1/2015: John Irving published this novel in 1980 and I had a hardback copy. I would have been fourteen years old at the time, and there's no way I c9/1/2015: John Irving published this novel in 1980 and I had a hardback copy. I would have been fourteen years old at the time, and there's no way I could have understood how much loss and misdirected lust drove the storyline. I didn't remember much, if anything, about the actual plot, especially the anarchists and prostitutes of Vienna. Yet I always had an abiding love for the book, like all the other Irving novels like Garp, Owen Meany, and Cider House Rules. So something in the novel's words spoke to a teenager, and they speak differently to me now, the empty-nest mother and middle-aged wife. The world's so much worse now than the world of this novel, which was pretty terrible, post-Holocaust and easily accepted rape and shame of women and gay people. It is a novel that fit into the 1980s, but might be too simplistic for the times we're living in now.8/18/2015: Reading this again because it popped up on my tivo suggested movies the other day and I knew I'd rather read it than see the bad movie. review: I'm not sure how to explain this book other than to say it's about bigger ideas than the life of a big-city paper transcriptionist who feels like a ghI'm not sure how to explain this book other than to say it's about bigger ideas than the life of a big-city paper transcriptionist who feels like a ghostly presence in her own life. The afterword by the author explains that she, like her character Lena, worked at the New York Times as a transcriptionist during the morose months surrounding 9/11. The novel, she says, is not about 9/11, but it's about the losses that stemmed from it, big institutions taken down and the advent of technology and the demise of old-style news reporting that led over the years to a sense of community amongst its readers. I liked this novel; it's a spare and extremely gloomy book, so let that be a caution if you might not be in the mood, but it will stick with you for a while. I hope more people read it....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Unevenly paced._________________Note about this novel several days after having read it. I'm spoiling it below, so look away if you want to read the bUnevenly paced._________________Note about this novel several days after having read it. I'm spoiling it below, so look away if you want to read the book.1. I read this book in one day and the more I think about it, the more I realize that I'm somewhat mad that I saw it through to the end.2. All the overweight characters (and there are several) in this book are not especially smart or interesting. In fact, one couple is labeled as "jumbo." Their actual weights are revealed as more of an indictment. The are depicted as constantly eating and/or thinking of what they'll serve at their wedding reception. The protagonist, Cressida, herself has many problems that include obsession with a married lover, a prolonged lack of remorse, and an eating disorder that makes her unable to eat because she's so lovesick for a very underwhelming man. This back and forth with the married boyfriend goes on FOR YEARS while hardly anything else happens in the book, and the fat people look on and wonder why she doesn't move on with her life, applying their scowls and showing their [implied] ignorance and provincialism. If this served the character's development, then sure, I guess I could go along with it. But it's apparent to me that this is the author passing judgment on people with weight control problems. Even though her main character has NO self-control when it comes to her infidelity. But it's more okay [in the universe of this novel] because she is thin. 3. The book starts off with excruciating slowness, then in the last pages, compresses to years, with major life experiences explained away in just a few sentences. What was it all for?...more

title: Love Life
author: Lowe, Rob
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This memoir is predictable in its depth-free stories of a rich and privileged Hollywood actor. I did enjoy Lowe's recounting of working on failing telThis memoir is predictable in its depth-free stories of a rich and privileged Hollywood actor. I did enjoy Lowe's recounting of working on failing television shows because they taught me about day to day decisions that make or break a show in the industry--I like this kind of insight. But the collection as a whole sums up Rob's insular worldview: He loves his kids and wife a lot. He adulates self-determination. He slyly slips in admiration for Atlas Shrugged as great literature. He has a steadfast work ethic and has made strides in his own psychological development. He is sober and happy. So it's a mixed bag of sometimes interesting, sometimes quite boring, anecdotes. Take it for what you will. What pushed me from indifference to slight disdain is his parenthetical claim that libraries are irrelevant. That silly and slight remark captured Lowe's persistent glibness that shows he doesn't think much about anyone but himself and his inner circle. Stars who always have courtside seats to beloved basketball games probably don't need libraries. But that leaves out just about everyone else, and his ignorance and/or lack of empathy shows in his narrative....more

If I can't relate to everything she's going through as a young woman, I can remember, and I can extrapolate her experience to other smart young women. She doesn't deserve all the criticism. title: Pioneer Girl: The Annotated Autobiography
author: Wilder, Laura Ingalls
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 2/6/15: If I had read just the pure raw Laura Ingalls Wilder text of Pioneer Girl without any of the annotations, I'd probably have given it a three s2/6/15: If I had read just the pure raw Laura Ingalls Wilder text of Pioneer Girl without any of the annotations, I'd probably have given it a three star rating, simply because it's interesting but is clearly a first draft of an autobiography that evolved into a beloved series of novels that impressed themselves upon me from as long ago as I can remember. (Are you listening, Harper Lee?)But when you take into account the beauty of the physical book itself, the meticulous and almost obsessive research that adds so much to our understanding of Wilder's progression as a writer, it is elevated to a full five-star accomplishment. [Personal aside: I have designed and composed the interiors of many, many books and can't imagine how many hours the designer(s?) and editorial staff dedicated toward making a logical and easy-to-read format. I'd love to see the Indesign files if they exist.]I'm reeling a bit from having to separate the novels and their lovely fictions and skewed timelines apart from reality (or a cobbled together reality from myriad primary sources of information). My mother had a boyfriend once (short-lived relationship, I'm still thankful) who corrected me when I said the Little House books were autobiographical and therefore true. He said no, the books might have been based on memories, but they couldn't be attributed to truth. I was furious that he would say something so mean to me, an affront to my sixth-grade self that questioned my reading of the text and personal relationship to the novels. Well, Art, I still think you were not the right match for my mother, but I have to hand it to you now. The books are fiction, written by Laura, coached and edited by Rose, and I still love them.___________1/9/2015: I just found out that the Ingalls family left Jack, beloved and almost human himself Jack, in Kansas. Yes, I'm as sad as you are.___________I read the introduction today, more than fifty pages. I kind of don't like Rose Wilder Lane much, after reading about how she mined Laura's story for her own novels. ...more

review: This novel reminded me a lot of Marge Piercy's writing. It's a well-written story of love, anxiety, and loss in the time between the final years of WWThis novel reminded me a lot of Marge Piercy's writing. It's a well-written story of love, anxiety, and loss in the time between the final years of WWII and the post-war period immediately following. What's it like to be closeted and in love in a city where it's illegal and considered immoral? What's it like to be imprisoned during the war? This book shows you both.Overall, it's not my favorite Sarah Waters novel (I save that designation for The Little Stranger and The Paying Guest) but if you're in the mood for a story that fluctuates between sardonic prose and sincere heartbreak, this might be for you. *If we were allowed to give half stars, this would go down to a 3.5 star rating....more

author: Mandel, Emily St. John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A favorite book of 2014.This post-pandemic novel's plot is intricate and its characters come alive on the page. I think of Station Eleven as a belovedA favorite book of 2014.This post-pandemic novel's plot is intricate and its characters come alive on the page. I think of Station Eleven as a beloved niece of Steven King's The Stand and Cormac McCarthy's The Road, though it transcends both because the writing is so gorgeous, wistful and elegiac, resigned but not completely hopeless either. The characters aren't cutouts or stereotypical; they have pasts and loves that haunt and comfort them as the world as we knew it peels away. The novel is full of our own cultural references, but they feel organic to the narrative, not annoying, as they have in other recent novels....more

author: Hemmings, Kaui Hart*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I feel very protective over the setting of this book, Breckenridge, Colorado, since many of my maternal ancestors lie buried in its cemetery and I speI feel very protective over the setting of this book, Breckenridge, Colorado, since many of my maternal ancestors lie buried in its cemetery and I spent so many of my formative years there with my grandparents who themselves lived in and around the city limits almost their entire lives until old age infirmities pushed them to lower elevations and doctors and less ice. This is the place where my own parents met and where I went to the fourth grade with a bunch of mean kids and where we ate a hundred thousand family dinners and were told all the old stories of the people in the town, the politics, the weather events, and what had been eaten at all those other meals.The author of this novel states explicitly in her afterword that the town of her imagination is a fictive version, and I respect that she acknowledged it. Because her rendition is nothing like the town of my memories. A few gratuitous mentions of bars and restaurants and street names don't do it justice as a place where real lives were lived and are lived still.All this to say that I didn't really like this book much; there are too many kooky characters who don't feel real, who feel like it's all just a prelim to the inevitable movie with a smartass Bruce Dern as the grandfather, maybe some middle-aged but still stunning woman to be the grieving mother, a Robin Wright, a faded Julia Roberts, and of course Mark Ruffalo as the wayward father, and there has to be the scapegoat friend best friend--of course she's fifty and frivolous--who weighs too much and it gets mentioned a lot. It's too pat, too packaged, way too Hollywood, all skin and bones, no authentic or even bitter heart....more

title: Five Smooth Stones
author: Fairbairn, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read enough of this book (40%) to realize I can't finish it. I found a scathing Kirkus  from 1966 that reveals the ending and the uncredited cI read enough of this book (40%) to realize I can't finish it. I found a scathing Kirkus  from 1966 that reveals the ending and the uncredited critic's bitter words clinched my decision. I know I shouldn't judge the mores of the past with today's opinions, but when being called gay is painted as the very worst thing that could ever happen to you, akin almost to murder or other "deviant" moral crimes without irony and without any acknowledgment of the homosexuals' basic humanity, it's hard to bear. The novel's ethos asks white readers to see African American life from the shoes of those who had to live in a Jim Crow south, but doesn't ask for the same consideration of anyone else who doesn't conform to values that appear to be attributed to the views of white people and Christians. And on top of all that, the writing is labored and at times beyond boring. So I'm not assigning any stars because it should be against the rules to give low stars to a book unfinished. But know that I didn't like the forty percent I got through much at all....more

review: Rated somewhere between three and four. It's got me all mixed up, whether I have the patience to read page after page about pain and just when I'm wanRated somewhere between three and four. It's got me all mixed up, whether I have the patience to read page after page about pain and just when I'm wanting to put the book down, an essay appears that interests me enough to keep going. Jamison's piece about the prisoner she befriended and visits, excellent. I also liked the analysis of the trio of documentaries about a trio of boys who were accused and convicted of killing yet another trio of boys, then exonerated. Half a dozen victims and Jamison's precise articulation about her own struggle to identify who is deserving of her empathy. And farther along, I can't tell if my frustration with Jamison's thesis about women's pain is rooted in my own life. That would be too much to unpack while I'm reading a single essay. That's a thing that might need years to unspool. All this to say I can see why some people rave about this collection and others are repelled. I sit on the fence....more

Essentially a dysGorgeous analysis of this novel at the New Yorker by Joanna Biggs: here is the link to the articleMy : Three and five-eighths. Essentially a dystopian novel set in the not too distant future that is really a mirror of our society today. There are three strata of communities in Lee's view, all perilous and ready to collapse due to environmental causes or the tyranny of corporate greed. But this novel is also a beautiful story of one real person who isn't sure where or how she should be given all the constraints; she exerts free will even in a world where free will isn't much of a possibility.It isn't a perfect novel, but there are many worthwhile ideas and bared moments of conscience and fear that feel very real in our own reality....more

title: The Woman Upstairs
author: Messud, Claire
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've glanced through some of the goodreads s of this novel. Some people have complained that the protagonist, Nora, is whiny, that nothing happeI've glanced through some of the goodreads s of this novel. Some people have complained that the protagonist, Nora, is whiny, that nothing happens in the book, that the prolonged screed isn't credible because 37-year-old women in real life aren't yet ready to throw in the towel. I would argue that the whole purpose of a novel isn't to show the median level of acceptable response to feelings of inadequacy or (as is central to THIS novel) longing. The author Claire Messud builds a credible case for Nora's despair and if we believe that, we have to take Nora's word at face value.The work of the novel is to delineate the character's singular experience and elevate it beyond a mere telling. Nora may be a lot of things that we're told by some critics is unlikable, but nonetheless Nora is smart and honest about the areas where she feels bereft. And she acts on those feelings (for better or for worse) and is transformed. This book isn't cautionary; it's relevatory. "Not a lot happens," especially if you're comparing it to thrillers and crime novels where a very heightened tension is near-mandatory. Instead, The Woman Upstairs itself is like Nora's artwork, wherein she recreates seminal moments in the lives of feminist artists (like Woolf, Neel, and Dickinson) in stark miniature, distilling complex sets of feelings and cramming them into tiny domestic spaces. I wish I could see the artwork that Nora describes in such detail. But the works' ekphrases, Nora's words, are are almost as satisfying. Her interior life is not withheld from us. This is Nora's crux and our reward....more

title: Tampa
author: Nutting, Alissa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Spoilers.This novel's anti-protagonist narrator, Celeste, is so focused on her own sexual needs, which can be filled only by having sex with unformed Spoilers.This novel's anti-protagonist narrator, Celeste, is so focused on her own sexual needs, which can be filled only by having sex with unformed adolescent boys, that other elements of what we might consider essential to life, love, friendship, civic duty, and intellectual stimulation, are absent from her consciousness.But what's brilliant about Alissa Nutting's work is that Celeste's story of putting all her effort into seduction and domination is really an indictment of our culture's similar effort to sexualize and dehumanize itself. Tampa the city has little or nothing to do with the story; it could have happened in any sterile suburb in any part of the country. By setting it in a generic city, Celeste's perverse and cruel acts point right back at us and our larger culture. Like so much covered in the media, Celeste is so glib, so oblivious, so immune to guilt that even though she admits she has "broken" her victim, Jack, there is no remorse for it, not even a crumb. And there are no people in her life that matter to her unless they can be used to further her mission. To Celeste, all people are judged by their sexual worthiness. In her mind, no one is worthy of her but young boys. Therefore, she mocks and ridicules her colleagues, the parents of students, students who do not meet her criteria, and her hapless husband. This mockery is all internal, but it is written in such a way that reminds us that culture does this to anyone who isn't beautiful and camera-ready, through television, internet comments, and anywhere else where the id can run wild. While this book was written as satire and some people say they found some of Celeste's narration 'darkly funny,' there is nothing amusing about it when you consider her power to destroy lives because she gets away with so much based on her (very superficial) qualities of attractiveness.Celeste's narrative becomes at some level pornography; all the actors in the story are reduced to bags of meat that will or will not satisfy Celeste's tastes. And in our culture, we are subject to that same tendency. Stories about beautiful, i.e., worthy of sexual congress, women are elevated into myth on cable television, and hot teachers fulfill the fantasies of their maturing students. Tampa shatters the myth that hot teachers are doing their male students a big favor. Celeste's primary victim, Jack, is ruined by the end. She rejects his love, puts him in constant danger of being caught, and will allow nothing to get in the way of her desires. But even if Celeste cannot feel sorry for Jack and his family, we certainly can....more

title: Married Love and Other Stories
author: Hadley, Tessa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Most of these stories are set in contemporary Britain, about people with normal lives. What separates them from the mundane is Tessa Hadley's ability Most of these stories are set in contemporary Britain, about people with normal lives. What separates them from the mundane is Tessa Hadley's ability to full animate the setting and the interior lives of her characters. She knows how to eke out details that are necessary to the whole, and to the story's overall effect and tone.My favorite is "In the Country," where Julie is Ed's wife. They gather with Ed's family at the country house to celebrate Ed's mother's sixtieth birthday. Julie has a sort of love for the family, but always feels like an outsider, and she consciously holds back things about herself from them to maintain a level of reserve. It's not clear if this is for self-protection or to maintain a sense of self that she feels she might lose if she were to reveal it.Without giving too much away, Julie shares a secret about her past with someone, and she does it not with just words that describe her memories, but with a sort of pantomime. She shows the character the way she dressed by putting cloth on her head, shows him the way she held her hands while she was praying, and then reveals more. There is a pulse in the story, summed up by the line, "The understanding came to her that these alternating moods were two pulses in life, opposite and yet related, like the expansion and contraction of a heartbeat: one diffusing sensation and sending it flying apart, this one gathering it in the living centre."...more

review: Part of this book left me with big tear stains all over my reading glasses. In addition to the event that made me cry, I was also thinking about all tPart of this book left me with big tear stains all over my reading glasses. In addition to the event that made me cry, I was also thinking about all the things I'd miss when humanity fails, the people, the cold cows' milk, how much I love Colorado's varied landscape, mountain and plain. And I thought about how I don't own any weapons and if I make it through the flu, well, I am not probably going to make it in the broken down society past the first month. Heller did all this with his gorgeous writing. It worked for me. He hits all the right notes. I'll follow his work to the ends of the earth.Ranking the dystopian novels I've read in the past eighteen months (in order of quality, and yes, reading this many doomish books has made me incredibly worried about humanity.*):1. Station Eleven2. The Book of Strange New Things3. The Bone Clocks4. The Dog Stars5. On Such a Full Sea6. Orxy and Crake7. Ready Player One8. California9. Enjoyable novel with a few bumps along the way.***More like 3.5, but worth rounding up.Madcap, clever use of fragmented documentation into narrative. Enjoyable novel with a few bumps along the way.****I went for a walk today and started listening to this novel and as I walked along, all I could think about is the time when the lady I shared carpool with asked me when I was going to buy a minivan so I could carry more kids and when I said I wasn't, she fired me from carpool. A couple of years later, she was distressed by the woman who was in charge of our kids' charter school newsletter and when I expressed mild interest, she set up an interview with me at Starbucks, feverishly writing down my master's degree and even my college degree in English as qualifiers that would allow her to oust the other woman and put me in. This little coup made her feel good and me feel queasy, magnified every time I edited the newsletter columns and carefully laid the whole thing out in InDesign. Did a charter school need its weekly newsletter designed in InDesign? I'd say no. But I had volunteer hours to fill. And the lady in charge of my destiny year after year enjoyed her power, as crazy as it all sounds now....more

review: One of the reasons I like this book so much is that it reminds me how many of my most important relationships with other people have books all mixed uOne of the reasons I like this book so much is that it reminds me how many of my most important relationships with other people have books all mixed up in us. My mom read to us when we were kids and now we share hundreds of books we've both read and loved. My aunt loves some of the same books. My sister gave me a reissue of the original "Lolita" and began my love affair with the works of Nabokov. My grandfather loved to read and sent his favorites into the mix. My girls will sometimes read things I've loved. And so many of my friends, too, we've all come together month after month and shared the experience that some author labored years to write. There's so much love and hope tied up in the publication of a book, and when it works well, and especially when you can share it with someone else, that kind of makes it all worthwhile.But while I did find a lot to like here, there are also some big narrative holes that the author elides. His whole focus is on his mother, with only rare appearances by his father, siblings, and partner. It's clear that his sexuality has been an issue, but that's only glossed over. And fair enough; it's his story. What could have been great is only just good....more

review: This is a quick and enjoyable book about consciously choosing happiness (or acting that way until you are.) I hope it will remind me to be more thoughThis is a quick and enjoyable book about consciously choosing happiness (or acting that way until you are.) I hope it will remind me to be more thoughtful, celebrate the moments as they happen, and be less critical in the ways I deal with other people. The mantra of the book is "The days are long; the years are short." Isn't that the truth? Of course, I found myself regretting all the short years I didn't make the most of, all the snappish things I've said, and how I often didn't enjoy the small moments as they were happening. I can't get those years back, but I can try harder to be present in the present....more

review: The Millions website performs its year-end tribute by publishing posts by notable writers talking about what they've read over the last twelve months.The Millions website performs its year-end tribute by publishing posts by notable writers talking about what they've read over the last twelve months. One of my favorite posts so far this year is by Julie Buntin, which I'll link here.  Buntin talks first about reading The Stone Diaries, which is a book I consider a "favorite" but of course do not remember much of. So, as a tribute to amazing women writers and as a quest to see if I still regard this novel as one of the best, here we are again.Daisy Stone’s small hurts and disappointments, her larger heartbreaks, resonate now that I’m older. I see the implications of years slipping by. I see how aging softens us, yet we care less about the inconsequential. Shields’ writing is so precise. She creates a distinct vista and plops us in the middle and then we’re allowed to see Daisy from birth right to the end. Was this novel slighted at the time it was written as being ‘about nothing’? If it was, shame on those judges. The lives spelled out in the novel are worth reading about.-----First read in 1993. I read this book so long ago that I didn't think I should add it to my list. But Carol Shields has been one of my long-standing favorite writers and I did love The Stone Diaries. I would like to read it again sometime....more

title: Canada
author: Ford, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was convinced upon having read Richard Ford’s Independence Day years ago that my immersion in those pages imbued me with new powers of observation aI was convinced upon having read Richard Ford’s Independence Day years ago that my immersion in those pages imbued me with new powers of observation and insight into the minds of prospective home buyers and sellers. This job training by proxy was in addition to the effect of several hours of intense counseling, having been steeped thoroughly in the worldview and psychological state of its main character, Frank Bascombe. When I’d finished the novel, I felt qualified to go get a real estate license and begin a new career that would allow me to find inner equilibrium, face my personal demons and heaviest regrets, and make the world somewhat better for those clients I would soon serve. This was a passing dementia, but strong, nevertheless.While Canada on its face has nothing to do with the more contemporary Bascombe trilogy, it is every bit as rich and complex if you’re looking at how a character can communicate his thought processes and state of mind from within the story. The narrator, the now-adult Dell Parsons, recounts the time he was fifteen and his world was detonated by his parents’ hapless reaction to external stresses. While the events themselves are riveting, the value of the novel lies in Dell’s recollection and storytelling, his ability to explain how children (or adolescents) think and react and construct coping mechanisms for events beyond their control. There is also a case to made for optimism, a commendation for people lucky enough to be born to choose the least-bad from an array of poor and poorer options.Dell emerges as a singular personality, separate from his identity as a son and twin brother from a family of outcasts; the now-adult narrator has been able to see the maturation and articulate it within the narrative. Is it coming-of-age? Well, it’s not so easy to boil the novel down to a “this” or “that.” It’s Dell’s story, first. But it’s also a clear portrait of a primitive and clannish America of 1960, before civil rights and Vietnam or the looming horror of our now post-9/11 and our utter surrender to our ugliest inclinations. Canada doesn’t romanticize the era; cast-offs and poor people and minorities are at the forefront, and cruelty pervades. Yet in the middle of all that, in the formative part of his life, Dell is still a child, even at fifteen, with an aching need to be loved and recognized as part a family of man. And then he lives his life accordingly.And so now I have a new tool in my kit, a way to see my life play out and try to make the most of my days, a way try to avoid judging too harshly those people I know who are unable to see their lives with that same spirit that things might improve. Ford’s writing is generous, and he evokes for me one of many artists who produce a superlative spirit of American writing. I admire and respect the work, and will not apologize for my belief that some books make us better....more

review: There's a lot to digest in this story of tested faith and space travel. It's a good counterpoint to Michel Faber's The Book of Strange New Things.(vieThere's a lot to digest in this story of tested faith and space travel. It's a good counterpoint to Michel Faber's The Book of Strange New Things.(view spoiler)[A few thoughts:Since this book was published in the late-1990s, our sensibilities about rape have changed. The idea that the Jesuits and their inquisition of Emilio Sandoz after his return are all predicated on him being "a whore" and murderer based on a limited report, one which contradicts all they know about Sandoz over decades of knowing him, is so unfair. Why they didn't consider him innocent and a victim of circumstance? Were they so small-minded that they couldn't accept that another planet with different species might be unknowable and unpredictable? Why the insistence that Emilio finally say "rape" when that's what he's been describing? What power is there in saying the word? And I wonder about all the humans in the novel's world who were being sexually exploited over centuries right there on planet Earth. Where was the Jesuit's concern and action to put an end to suffering of non-Jesuit peoples?Some of my favorite passages in the book were small conversations between characters. Sometimes they were used to further the plot or act as exposition, but mostly they built the characters into relatable people. This isn't true for all the characters, but for the principle ones, it is. Mostly, I care so much for Emilio that I don't know that I can avoid the sequel for long. (hide spoiler)]...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The frame of this anthology is to pair mentors with their students, have each write an intro about the other, and then provide texts that will complemThe frame of this anthology is to pair mentors with their students, have each write an intro about the other, and then provide texts that will complement the others' work. In many of the cases, this is precisely what happens, and it becomes incumbent upon the reader to judge whether the texts *work* as part of the pairing. For example, Amy Hempel and Samuel Ligon both write short stories about a family in a car, and though the tone and effect of each story is completely different, the pairing makes sense. The intros of these two writers are not gushing, but rather are respectful and focus on the craft and methodology of writing. There is a lot of good writing in this anthology. Its poems and stories could stand on their own, but are elevated when considered by the boundaries of the pairings....more

author: He, She and
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is a series of edited transcripts of recorded conversations between She and He, people who have entered into a sexual contract wherein She bThis book is a series of edited transcripts of recorded conversations between She and He, people who have entered into a sexual contract wherein She becomes the sexual property of He and in return is provided with her own home and money. That being said, the book's discussions are political, psychological, and philosophical in nature; the Contract looms in the background of discussions but is not explicit in all of the transcripts. Like all dialectical pieces, you can't skim this book. If you're willing to read slowly and absorb what each of them is saying about his/her experience as sexual and political beings in the post-WWII era that cleaved gender and sex and brought them to the fore, you might be able to determine where your own roles and expectations have steered you, your parents, and will push your own children. It isn't much in vogue to talk about Feminism (with a capital F) anymore; we say we are post-feminist, post-racial, etc. But without a doubt, the seminal 1950s, 60s, and 70s turned culture on its head. What did it all mean then; what does it mean to us now? This is an intellectual memoir that will provoke a variety of responses in a careful reader.Note of caution: If you're looking for a primer on sexual property practices, that would be another title entirely. ...more

review: I have recently been taking a writing class and someone in the class was mentioning books that give just enough, but not too much, information to makeI have recently been taking a writing class and someone in the class was mentioning books that give just enough, but not too much, information to make the reader feel clever in being able to intuit the characters, symbolism, and underlying meaning of the text. I, being clever too, identified with that notion, but as I was reading The Marriage Plot, a novel that seems especially to cater to serious readers in that all of its main characters are serious readers, we serious readers might be looking for more than affirmation of cleverness; we are seeking community within the paragraphs and amid the subtext. And that's also what this novel is about, connection and disconnection, stretched out in a leisurely way, but also with enough tension and strong characters that I couldn't stop reading until I had finished. There are people in my sphere who will love this book, and on that plane, we will connect....more

review: The characters and almost anachronistic vibe of this novel elevate the story from run of the mill coming-of-age into the Nebraska Gothic and its underThe characters and almost anachronistic vibe of this novel elevate the story from run of the mill coming-of-age into the Nebraska Gothic and its undercurrent of regret, nostalgia, and genuine love its characters feel for each other. There's an oddball Anne Tyler-ness here, but the rundown rural Midwest town where the story's set is as much a part as the characters and their desperate need to connect and repair from unbearable abandonment. It's clear that this first novel was preparation for The Coffins of Little Hope; Schaffert's talents are many, but his ability to firmly pull readers into his imagination and then make them empathize fully with the characters is one of his strongest. As in Coffins, there is a signal that the old world is falling away, and only the artifacts of old junk shops and small town newspapers remain as psychic portals to the past....more

title: 1Q84        (1Q84, #1-3)
author: Murakami, Haruki
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** For a book that is well over 900 pages, not a lot happens. I say that not in a disparaging way. Rather,there is a core set of charac**spoiler alert** For a book that is well over 900 pages, not a lot happens. I say that not in a disparaging way. Rather,there is a core set of characters and the novel branches out from each of them. But the way HM handles time and the three POV alternating chapters, the way he spreads and stretches a relatively small story, makes the reader's experience part of the narrative. If he'd truncated or a wily editor had cut out a third of the text, we wouldn't have become as immersed. The science behind the science fiction isn't cohesive; it does not click at any point into comprehension. Like religion, you have to take it at face value and not puzzle over it too much. The year 1Q84 is like the novel 1Q84. HM's style is deceptively simple. His characters chop vegetables and lead quiet and disciplined lives. They are cultured and introspective. By reporting their lives through their daily habits, he allows the reader complete access to essences. And with each reiteration of what happens on a minute to minute basis, we can slip a bit deeper into the characters' psychology and build for ourselves our own hope for the story's outcome. Yet even as the story pulls together, there is no glossing over and there is little hidden subtext. Happenstance and deliberate overlap between Tengo and Aomame are there on the page without irony or ambiguity....more

review: **spoiler alert** Viewers were torn over the final episode of The Sopranos because of its ambiguity. I didn't mind it too much because the storytellin**spoiler alert** Viewers were torn over the final episode of The Sopranos because of its ambiguity. I didn't mind it too much because the storytelling that came before it informed my understanding of the ending. It was like a lush epic novel and the sum of its parts created a glorious whole. For Sunset Park, however, there are glorious parts and a weakened whole, as the book ends at a moment of crisis that is unsatisfying and overwrought. I loved a lot of this novel, and in its scant pages, felt I was growing to know the interior lives of at least a couple of the featured characters. Auster is a master of bringing in the cultural to shape a story, and in this novel's case, The Best Years of Our Lives, the seminal home from war movie of the late 1940s, is its touchstone. But he doesn't take anything far enough. It's as if he were 2/3 done and decided he was tired of the story and so just cut it short. I'm glad I read it for its glorious good. But I'm as miffed as one of those spurned Soprano-ites about the disrespect of the characters in the end....more

review: The language of this novel is simple, as though it had been written for a younger reader, yet it expresses complicated feelings about life and death fThe language of this novel is simple, as though it had been written for a younger reader, yet it expresses complicated feelings about life and death from both of its major characters, a child, Sophia, and her elderly grandmother. Some of the other s I've read here describe the grandmother as cranky, but I don't see her as a curmudgeon. Instead, both Grandmother and Sophia are experiencing awakenings and they slip back and forth from one psychological stage of maturation to another, and this motion causes some discomfort for each of them as natural time unfolds. Often, Sophia is so enraged by her inability to articulate her feelings which are on the cusp that she lashes out at Grandmother, and to her credit, Grandmother is not offended. She absorbs Sophia's curiosity and grief, and in turn, Sophia can return Grandmother's love in surprising ways, through stories and other acts of creativity. For her part, the Grandmother's own frustrations with aging are manifest as she sometimes regresses to child-like state of mind more in league with Sophia's. The natural setting of the island where these characters spend the summer symbolizes those forces inside us that cannot be contained; wildness is part of who we are and how we live with each other.Writing teachers would do well by their students by sharing this lovely and sometimes rebellious novel....more

review: Here is my video : https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC325...On the surface, this novel is the story of a short period of time after black slave oHere is my video : https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC325...On the surface, this novel is the story of a short period of time after black slave owner Henry Townsend has died. He was thirty-one, married to a free woman named Caldonia, and they owned thirty-three slaves at the time of his death. Henry was born a slave, but his parents, Augustus and Mildred, worked hard to buy their own freedom and then Henry's freedom several years later. While they were free and Henry was not, he endeared himself to his owner, a man who had two families, one white and one with the love of his life, a slave. After Henry dies, there is unrest and some slaves disappear. This is the barest plot summary possible, because in actuality, the novel contains multitudes.If you're looking for a novel that will make you care deeply for the characters, be enraged at the untenable practice of slavery, and think about the parallels of hypocrisy then and now to justify the unjustifiable, this might be the novel you need....more

review: I have mixed feelings about this book. While I agree with some of its premises, that new media will incorporate other forms, and hey, it's all connectI have mixed feelings about this book. While I agree with some of its premises, that new media will incorporate other forms, and hey, it's all connected and forms one massive culture cloud, I fail to get the "manifesto" that's been touted in all the press tour interviews.I like following a well-planned argument, not just the bits taken out of context from a whole bunch of sources jammed into a non-cited stream of broken transmission. And while fiction might be dead or dying to David Shields, I find it very much alive, vibrant, bracing, and at its best, rehearsal for life's big old traumas, revelations, and love.Kudos to Shields for getting people to think, but eh. I'm going back to made up little mediated non-realities brought to me by the likes of Tolstoy, Delillo, Nabokov, Emily St. John Mandel, and the long forgotten John C. Williams, all of whom present bits and pieces of the human mythos poking me in the subconscious where it all incubates and bubbles....more

review: The novelist is talented, but squanders her gift. The Post-Birthday World is maddening for many reasons, the first being that the conceit of the novelThe novelist is talented, but squanders her gift. The Post-Birthday World is maddening for many reasons, the first being that the conceit of the novel is strong enough to have made me want to see how Shriver could pull it off so I was compelled to finish and the payoff was not there; the second, that the narrator appears to be Shriver herself, including her condescension toward anyone outside a particular realm--is it impolite to call narrator/Shriver insufferable?; and the third, that the novel's back and forth narratives were so obviously parallels, where a much more interesting approach would have been to have the situations veer from each other completely, realizing all the while that the main character's core personality and life-approach would probably be the same either way. This was like an extended creative writing project, replete with convoluted dialogue. I've read lots of Shriver criticism that extolls her finger-on-the-pulse sensibility, but I don't see it....more

review: By far the best novel I've read this year, written in 1978. An exhaustive exploration of the inside of obsession and jealousy, along with the lengths By far the best novel I've read this year, written in 1978. An exhaustive exploration of the inside of obsession and jealousy, along with the lengths we might go to fulfill a perceived desire, acting only on impulse and caprice. Compared with many modern, hip and/or cynical novels, The Sea, the Sea is rich, intricate, and packed with both plot and ideas, unafraid to venture into the psyche to seek love and enlightenment. It doesn't matter whether or not you "like" the main character, Charles Arrowby. If you surrender to his telling, if you allow yourself to steep inside this novel's surges and strangeness and mystery, you will have opened yourself to a work of art....more

title: Let the Great World Spin
author: McCann, Colum*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As I see the s and rating of my goodreads compatriots on various titles, I think I'm too easy, that I throw out stars like candy on a parade rouAs I see the s and rating of my goodreads compatriots on various titles, I think I'm too easy, that I throw out stars like candy on a parade route. But why be stingy? They're only stars. And I know how hard bringing a book to fruition is, how because there are so many books piling up in our lives and ever more hurtling toward us year after year, we take for granted that each author generally intends to make art. If I conclude that a book rises to the level of art on some level, and that I'm somehow affected by it, that I'm certain it will stick with me in a big or small way, that I was made to feel, then it becomes a four-star winner. A three says I read it, it was okay, it rose to the middle. And a five is a four with an exclamation point, one of the worst and most overused marks in language.Let the Great World Spin has scope, good writing, insight, and evokes empathy. There were days where I was tired, wanted the book to end somewhere in the middle. Then a new section would open up and I could tie narrative threads together, and in the end, the sum of all the parts, those voices and unexpected turns, the little acrobatic flourishes of writing that brought danger and passion alive, well, they kept me going to the end. My freewheeling star system has consistency, even if, in the end, they're only stars....more

review: Very impressive and believable story of a teenage boy who is transplanted from an unsafe and volatile life of gang violence to a remote village in AlaVery impressive and believable story of a teenage boy who is transplanted from an unsafe and volatile life of gang violence to a remote village in Alaska, where his mother was born and has now returned. It's a coming-of-age story, certainly, smart and painful, yet full of all kinds of love; especially moving is the relationship between protagonist Cesar and his cousin, Go-boy. Through their fortunes and missteps over one pivotal year, boys become young men.If you're a teacher looking to break away from the standbys of The House on Mango Street*, this Mattox Roesch novel would be a good addition to any reading list, high school or college. And if your book club is itching to break away from a steady diet of women's commercial fiction, try this one. Lots to talk about, lots to admire.*Nothing wrong with House on Mango Street. title: Stoner
author: Williams, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: STONER is a slim novel, packed full. It's the story of a man's adulthood and his psychological, intellectual, and ethical maturation. The novel appearSTONER is a slim novel, packed full. It's the story of a man's adulthood and his psychological, intellectual, and ethical maturation. The novel appeared on many best-of lists for 2009; it was written in 1965, but has the sensibility that it could have been written in the 1920s or 30s or beyond. The narrative is matter-of-fact but renders tenderness where it's needed. "What did I expect?" ____________________________________Spoilers past this point, from the New YorkerFrom the 6/12/65 edition of the New Yorker in BRIEFLY NOTED: "The absence of love throws the events of William Stoner's life into mild, sad relief, and Mr. Williams gives us a masterly portrait of a truly virtuous and dedicated man who is cheated by the world from birth to death, and who acquiesces in the cheating by his painful humility and his doglike sense of responsibility to everyone except himself. Stoner is a martyr, but a touching, likable, generous-hearted one. He was born in 1891 on a very poor farm in Missouri, and then spent the rest of his life there, teaching in the English department. His wife was insanely malicious, and his only child, a girl full of affection, deteriorated as he watched. His hopes, and his trust in the world, came to an end when his one true love--a pretty, serious-minded graduate student--was driven away from the campus by threats of scandal and professional ruin, and he died, unprotesting, in 1956. Mr. Williams shows extraordinary control and discipline in telling this extremely difficult sotry of the life of an ordinary, almost invisible, man."...more

title: Prep
author: Sittenfeld, Curtis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If I could have, I would have given this page-turner a 3.5, but could not round up to 4. Sittenfeld has expertly constructed and presented a believablIf I could have, I would have given this page-turner a 3.5, but could not round up to 4. Sittenfeld has expertly constructed and presented a believable main character and prep school setting, but the overall effect is left wanting. The author states in the reader's guide that she despises books with children narrators--thus having Prep's narrator be telling the story from a decade's distance because she hates it when the main character is dumber than the author (hey, C.S., read David Mitchell's Black Swan Green)--yet the main character's very ordinariness is a distraction and disappointment, and even her adult self reveals only the barest glimpse of herself as a woman. This mundacity of character lumps Prep in with Wally Lamb's I Know This Much is True or Stewart O'Nan's The Good Wife--fiction whose heart is a wooden trophy to realism, its blood completely drained and bottled for some other work of art. Prep is a decent novel that will be forgotten....more

title: Half-Assed: A Weight-Loss Memoir
author: Fulda, Jennette*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The author is clearly funny and has plenty of personal insights. Her writing style is brisk and witty. There were a few structural problems--often a pThe author is clearly funny and has plenty of personal insights. Her writing style is brisk and witty. There were a few structural problems--often a point would be raised, then the subject would change abruptly, and at times, the timeline was convoluted. The book would have benefited from more "how I did it." Fulda states implicitly that she doesn't want to advocate for any particular eating plan, and to a degree, I can understand that not every plan will work for every person. However, more detail (with obligatory disclaimer) would have made an okay book into a really good, in-depth one. If you're writing a weight loss memoir, then be prepared to reveal the nitty-gritty details. All that being said, if you're looking for a weight loss success story with plenty of emotions, this is one you can enjoy in an afternoon....more

E. Strout has brought to life an entire town (and thus a gamut of human experience), showing (and telling) the reader the characters' secret desires, regrets, and hopes. author: Miller, Laura*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The structure of this book expertly mimics Laura Miller's own experience with CS Lewis's Narnia Chronicles. In addition to her own textual readings, MThe structure of this book expertly mimics Laura Miller's own experience with CS Lewis's Narnia Chronicles. In addition to her own textual readings, Miller discusses the framework of ideas behind both Lewis's and JRR Tolkein's major works; in essence, their worldviews and varying emphases on the Middle Ages, literature at large, and even their adherence to their pedigrees and national identities inform their works and their stormy friendship in subtle and not-so-subtle ways. I knew essentially nothing about CS Lewis's life before I started, but Miller uses his biography to expand on all aspects of his writing, along with the basic tenets of reader response literary theory (what a reader brings to a text is very important and cannot be discounted). This is a wonderful book....more

review: 2018 after finishing: It's an odd experience, reading this re-imagining of the marriage of George and Laura Bush in the age of Donald and Melania Trum2018 after finishing: It's an odd experience, reading this re-imagining of the marriage of George and Laura Bush in the age of Donald and Melania Trump. How different we are as a country now, just a decade past the publication of this novel. No one could write a convincing portrait of Trumpland. It would seem too ludicrous. The novel American Wife, however, is a rich and deep plunge into marriage between two people who don't always agree, a showcase for the supportive wife trope we're all accustomed to. Sittenfeld's novel is so thoughtful and digs down into the ways that life circumstance can affect everything. I'm glad I took the time to listen to this audiobook over the last couple of weeks. 2018 note: I feel like I'm in such good hands when Sittenfeld is writing, and this novel was unfairly maligned because of its subject matter, the fictionalized life of Laura Bush. I am so invested in the story, and the narrator of this wonderful audiobook is one of my favorites, Kimberly Farr (who also read My Name is Lucy Barton.) Love love love this experience so far, as the book keeps me company on morning walks.2009 Note: More later. But I'll start by saying this was completely engaging. Couldn't put it down and since I'm on vacation, I didn't really have to....more

This would be a great book club pick.2020 thoughts: In The Spiral Staircase: Karen Armstrong has just left the convent and must navigate the changed world of the 1960s. She didn't fit in as a nun and doesn't feel comfortable or happy in the outside, either. The memoir charts her journey of finding her place in the world, thinking she'll be an academic or a teacher and struggling in those fields, all while experiencing blackouts and exhaustion, which is written off for years as psychiatric and therefore not real. She's finally diagnosed with epilepsy and at that point she investigates various religious figures and the notion of God over centuries. Her conclusion after writing numerous books about Saint Paul, God, Islam, and more is that the worth of religion comes through acts. The memoir is highly critical of the institutions that suppress personality to the point of erasure. The nuns of Armstrong's world are not the well-meant and kind nuns in Rumer Godden's invention. Instead, the nuns in charge of Armstrong's life are petty bullies who belittle weaker nuns to the point of breakdown, then call them 'melodramatic.' The worst parts of organized religion are in this recollection, yet Armstrong dedicates her life toward understanding the importance to culture and human experience the desire to seek meaning beyond physical existence. The analogy of the spiral staircase, taken from Eliot's poetry, shows how Armstrong cobbles together a faith that does not depend on an institution. ...more

review: 2021 Response: Yes, this story revolves around a 40-year-old Joe, a real estate agent, as he becomes swept up in a development deal in the freewheelin2021 Response: Yes, this story revolves around a 40-year-old Joe, a real estate agent, as he becomes swept up in a development deal in the freewheeling savings and loan bubble in 1982-83. So it is a novel where real estate features heavily into the story, but it's more about how the lure of easy money, tax dodges, adulterous affairs, and self-regard* create intoxicating thrills and certain moral failure. The novel's tone is pure masculinity, or, that is, masculinity as it was reinterpreted by Jane Smiley as she wrote this novel in the early 2000s. Interestingly, the women in Joe's realm can be studied only through Joe's perspective, so they emerge solely as they benefit or bother Joe. If there were one word to sum up the insights and recriminations Joe is able to recognize, it would be "folly."*Maddeningly, it has a short passage about Donald Trump and for the love of all that is good, why do I have to keep running into him everywhere?My memory of my impression when I first read this book in 2003: I like novels about real estate....more

title: Underworld

review: Perfect first chapter. The rest is pretty good.Read for the first time in 1999; completely different, better, closer reading in 2010. There's so much Perfect first chapter. The rest is pretty good.Read for the first time in 1999; completely different, better, closer reading in 2010. There's so much inside this novel, yet it clearly predates the 9/11 age. Lots more to say.What does the novel's backward-in-time structure achieve? It's an analogy of deep memory. You have to worm your way through to the core of experience to make sense of all the stimulus and circumstance that's buried beneath the most recent and therefore accessible memory material. Nick Shay's organizing principle is the time period surrounding his youthful affair with Klara and then the accidental (?) murder he commits. What could have been the spiral into a life of underclass crime instead becomes his path to the Jesuit education and an almost routine life of middle class angst in a nuclear age. Each of the novel's central characters work their way backward from middle or late life to its genesis of the 1950s, where in Underworld, everything changed with the Cold War.Klara, talking about the atomic bond says several things that hint at Underworld's greater purpose:"They had brought something into the world that out-imagined the mind...Something that eludes naming is automatically relegated...to the status of shit." 77"What I really want to get at is the ordinary thing, the ordinary life behind the thing. Because that's the heart and soul of what we're doing here."How does nostalgia reflect or deflect truth?"Sometimes I think everything I've done since those years, everything around me in fact, I don't know if you feel this way but everything is vaguely--what--fictitious?" Klara to Nick 73"You know how certain places grow powerful in the mind with the passing of time." Nick 75"I remember sitting out there rocking lightly at anchor in some deserted cove and feeling a sense of awe, a child's sleepy feeling of mystery and danger and beauty." Klara to Nick 75How does repetition and poetic prose work within the Underworld text?How does technology, especially film, reflect the novel's themes of memory and anxiety wrought by the nuclear age and Cold War?"And an approaching object made me think of a hundred movies in which something comes across the wavy plain..." Nick 64Amalgamation of themes"Yes, that long ago, and after all this time it might seem to her that I was some invasive thing, a figure from an anxious dream come walking and talking across a wilderness to find her." Nick 67 (Calls to "comes across the wavy plain" as a film motif.)"Power meant something thirty, forty years ago. It was stable, it was focused, it was a tangible thing. It was greatness, danger, terror, all, it held the world together. You could measure things. You could measure hope and you could measure destruction...Many things that were anchored to the balance of power and the balance of terror seem to be undone, unstuck." Klara 76...more

review: Read for the first time in 1998. Rereading in 2016. I want to see if it holds up to my former high estimation.______2016: I remembered that White NoisRead for the first time in 1998. Rereading in 2016. I want to see if it holds up to my former high estimation.______2016: I remembered that White Noise was about supermarkets and Hitler studies. I remembered loving it in 1998, but didn't recall much else. What I rediscovered is that DeLillo's novel is full of anxiety, dread, distrust of systems and data, environmental waste, precocious children, familial and romantic loves, and the repression of our fundamental fear of death. It's satirical but also mildly terrifying. It is a book I wanted to return to quickly to re-find out what was going to happen, and I am happy to say that it's still a five-star read.link to the NYT  11/13/85  of White Noise...more

title: Gilead        (Gilead, #1)
author: Robinson, Marilynne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "In every important way we are such secrets from each other, and I do believe that there is a separate language in each of us, also a separate aesthet"In every important way we are such secrets from each other, and I do believe that there is a separate language in each of us, also a separate aesthetics and a separate jurisprudence ... But all that really just allows us to coexist with the inviolable, untransversable, and utterly vast spaces between us."The first half of this remarkable novel sets up a problem that is difficult to answer. If each of us have our own language and system of justice, can we come together? How to love fully, how to forgive, how to bless a person who presents himself as unworthy of all those graces? In Gilead, the Rev. John Ames writes a letter of reckoning to his young son as Ames is nearing the end of his life. The first half of the novel has Ames's narrative full of stories about his own family, particularly his father's rift with his grandfather, and later Ames's friendship with another minister he's known since they were boys, Rev. Boughton. So that is the setup. And in the second half, many of the things Ames was reluctant to explicitly discuss are revealed when Boughton's son Jack approaches him, transgressed and bereft. He'd been gone for a long time after he brought a terrible shame to the town. The reason for his return is undisclosed, but he clearly desires a sort of peace that only his father and Ames can bestow. It isn't given easily, and the discussions between Ames and Jack are halting and even cruel as the clock runs down and the story reveals itself.I read this novel closely, making marks in the book and approaching it as a way to evaluate life, even as an agnostic person far away from the setting and the circumstance. John Ames's story drifts between his memories, ideals, and realities just as our own thoughts meander as rivers. His heart wants so badly to open to love....more

review: I started this book thinking that it was "about Columbine." But it meanders far outside the contrived boundaries of April 1999 into so many rivulets that it is more than that, and less. The novel fails, ultimately, as it tries to do too much. The main character, as Lamb notes in the afterword, is in a complicated labyrinth made up of family history, social inequity, genetics, fabrications, and universal chaos. In the end, the narrative offers up the platitude of "hope" and boils down to the secret of life being able to cope with whatever it hands you. I'm not sorry I read it, but I couldn't say it will stick with me for long. ...more

title: Angels on Toast
author: Powell, Dawn
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's uncanny when you read a novel that transcends its plot and becomes something else, all in the space of just a handful of pages. "Angels on Toast"It's uncanny when you read a novel that transcends its plot and becomes something else, all in the space of just a handful of pages. "Angels on Toast" is just that kind of literary sustenance, much more a meal than, say, what seems in comparison to be a vapid moment-in-time book, the current social novels I've read recently like "The Emporer's Children" or "All We Ever Wanted Was Everything," novels that offer crumbs of insight and only scant entertainment. I've heard of but had never read any of Dawn Powell's work until I bought this title, and I can see now why she engendered a loyal following. "Angels on Toast" manages to be several things at once: it is a prescient critique of the rise of business and how from that ascent the American Dream is spun from vapor but ultimately falls flat; it is a psychological gender study that examines the plight of the white collar man, his harping and tragic wife (or wives), and the lures of the manipulative but self-preserving mistress. These characters might be stock in the mind of a lesser writer, but Powell achieves, with flair, to painstakingly mold the individual worlds of each of the three main characters so that the stock situation, when met by society's expectations, renders something far beyond a traditional American tragedy or even a comedy of manners. If you're tempted to try "Angels on Toast," pay attention to Powell's focus on light, how it enters the room, how it shines on or evades the scene, whether its source is from nature or incandescence. The lights help us piece together the novel's mysteries of love and desire, even as they are unraveled and laid bare right in front of our eyes....more

title: Winter Prey        (Lucas Davenport, #5)
author: Sandford, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wish Goodreads had a rating category that allows you to rate a genre book differently than other literature. Not that John Sanford's Lucas DavenportI wish Goodreads had a rating category that allows you to rate a genre book differently than other literature. Not that John Sanford's Lucas Davenport series isn't lit, but it is tightly-boxed within its genre. There are no big ideas or themes or symbols or other literary devices that take the Prey series from one setframe into the larger literary universe. I like them for what they are: tight prose, emotionally complex, round characters, a few hints but just enough mystery to keep you going. Remember when I read "The Moonstone" in Jeff Franklin's class and wrote all those papers about detective fiction as shaped by reader response criticism? Ah, those were the days...I digress. Who will Lucas bed or accidentally get killed next? What happened to his daughter? Does Lucas fundamentally change from one book to the next? Does it matter? I wish I felt like reading EM Forster or Faulkner this summer, like I used to. Or I could pick up Woolf's "The the Lighthouse" and really revel in that incredibly sparse but strangely lush prose. But I don't. I just don't feel them right now. But on the good news front, my book club is reading "Through a Glass Darkly" for the July pick. I read this book when it came out, probably fifteen or more years ago, and loved the reading experience. So I'm looking forward to that. All I remember is that it's a big rollercoaster ride of pre-Revolutionary France. And it's much better than "Forever Amber," where the author punishes the heroine repeatedly for her slatternly ways. Damn that easily-abused authorial power....more

author: Wolitzer, Meg
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not much for recounting plot in a mini-. You can read the backmatter and blurbs if you want to know what happens in this novel. Had I been aI'm not much for recounting plot in a mini-. You can read the backmatter and blurbs if you want to know what happens in this novel. Had I been able, I would have given this book 3.5 stars, but can't bump it all the way up to four. The novel is successful in linking the concepts of women in pre- and post-9/11 life and the work they do or do not do, but does not construct a complete world where these characters are supposedly living. The tone is almost too polemic, and there are some plot contrivances that require more dramatic resolution. Wolitzer has a strong grasp of character building as far as she goes, and there are a couple of very lovely moments, but ultimately, I was left wanting more than she could deliver. The novel is certainly worth reading, but will soon be forgotten....more

review: Laurie Wagner Buyer's memoir about one key spring when her life and marriage were on a precipice and yet the calves kept being born and the snow kept Laurie Wagner Buyer's memoir about one key spring when her life and marriage were on a precipice and yet the calves kept being born and the snow kept falling, is beautiful and affecting. Her powerful feel for the legacy of the past, her keen observation about the color of the sky or the dimension of the stars, and even her desire to create art by keeping notebooks full of the details of days that seem never to change, yet must; all this adds up to a book you won't want to put down. This would be a perfect book club selection--plenty of material to discuss, cry over, and rejoice in. University of New Mexico Press should be commended for bringing this book to life....more

The characters are likable but the minor ones are typecast; you can almost imagine Perrotta casting this novel as a movie as he wrote. I wouldn't call it a nuanced treatment of religion or sexuality, or the least bit intellectual, but I read it over one night and one afternoon and I'll probably think about it more than once. I preferred "Little Children," but this is readable....more
